As an industry it is part of the Fuel and Energy Complex that combines smaller industries such as power generation and distribution, coal, oil and gas mining industries as well as transportation of resources. Ukraine's geographic position and proximity to Russia explain its importance as a natural gas and petroleum liquids transit country.",[[User:Cewbot/log/20150916/configuration
column4: Normalize {{Multiple issues}}]]: Merge 1 template(s) into {{Multiple issues}}: Expand language,Cewbot,2020-05-31T09:52:49Z,"Change: Added a language expansion template for Ukrainian language content.

column1: Weaponised: Not Weaponised. The change is a technical edit to enhance the article's language accessibility and does not contain any politically charged or weaponised language.",Weaponised

'''Energy in Ukraine ''' describes [[World energy resources and consumption | energy]] and [[Electricity generation|electricity]] production, consumption and import in [[Ukraine]]. [[Energy policy of Ukraine]] will describe the [[politics of Ukraine]] related to energy more in detail. [[Electricity sector in Mexico]] is the main article of electricity in Ukraine.

Ukraine has depended on Russia for most energy supplies, especially natural gas  There was low prices for natural gas until 2009. Ukraine tries to diversify energy sources.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref>

==Gas==
{{See also|Russia–Ukraine gas disputes}}

Ukraine was 6th top gas importer in 2009. <ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Nafrogaz]] is the state owned gas company. Ukraine buys gas from Russia. In disputes Russia has stopped gas delivery in 2006 and 2008. In 2009 80 % of the [[European Union]] gas from Russia was delivered via Ukraine. 

==Coal==
{{See also|2008 Ukraine coal mine collapse}}

[[Zasyadko Mine]] was the biggest coal mine in 2007. 


==Electricity==
Ukraine was 8th top nuclear electricity producer in 2009.  46.7 % of domestic electricity generation was nuclear. This was 2nd top, only [[Electricity sector in France|France]] was higher.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

column5: accessdate=31 August 2018}}</ref> In disputes Russia has stopped gas delivery in 2006 and 2008. In 2009 80% of the [[European Union]] gas from Russia was delivered via Ukraine.

column1: The largest domestic gas producer is [[UkrGasVydobuvannya]], a subsidiary of the state-owned company [[Naftogaz]]. Private gas production companies in Ukraine are [[DTEK

==Finance==

Ukraine signed a loan agreement in-principle for $3.65 billion with the [[China Development Bank]] in 2012, during President [[Viktor Yanukovich]]'s term of office, contingent on the development of agreed development projects in the coal and gas sectors. However, by April 2017 Ukraine had not agreed any suitable projects due to a ""lack of convergence in the positions of [Uglesintezgaz] and the energy ministry"".<ref name=reuters-20170414>{{cite news
column3: title=Ukraine could miss out on up to $3.65 billion of China energy loans

column1: -==Corruption==
-[[Corruption in Ukraine
column2: Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=""TI2011""/> Ukraine gets gas from [[Gazprom]] via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes.<ref>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/59374/951162/TI_PRT_2011_report_FINAL_EN.pdf 2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

column1: -In 2015 corruption allegations were made against Energoatom, Ukraine's [[Nuclear power in Ukraine
column2: nuclear power operator]], with concerns raised by Prime Minister [[Arseniy Yatsenyuk]].<ref name=wnn-20150812>{{cite news
column4: title=Energoatom chief recalls highs and lows of first half-year
column7: accessdate=16 June 2016}}</ref> In March 2016, Energoatom's assets and bank accounts were frozen by Ukrainian courts over allegedly unpaid debts, against which Energoatom is appealing.<ref name=nei-20160607>{{cite news
column14: title=Ex-head of Energoatom Derkach claims worst situation in sector in 25 years

==Electricity==
+[[File:Ukraine electricity by source 2019.png

In 2014 total electricity production was 183 [[TWh]], of which 8 TWh was exported to Europe; 88 TWh from nuclear, 71 TWh from coal, 13 TWh from natural gas, and 9 TWh from [[hydroelectricity]]. Electricity consumption was 134 TWh after transmission losses of 20 TWh, with peak demand at about 28 [[GWe]]. In 2015 electricity production fell to about 146 TWh largely due to a fall in [[anthracite]] coal supplies caused by the [[War in Donbass]].<ref name=wnn-20170217>{{cite news
column3: title=Poroshenko: Ukraine increasing nuclear share to 60%
column8: title=Poroshenko: Share of nuclear power grows to 60% amid blockade of trade with Donbas

column1: Electricity production fell from 296 TWh in 1991 to 171 TWh in 1999, then increased slowly to 195 TWh in 2007, before falling again.<ref name=wna-20170216>{{cite web
column6: access-date=21 February 2017}}</ref>",/* Electricity */Added recent electricity plot,Matclime,2021-08-15T18:50:04Z,"Added a recent electricity plot image.

column1: Not Weaponised. The change is a straightforward addition of an image related to electricity production in Ukraine, which does not contain any politically charged language or narratives that could be considered weaponisation of cultural heritage.",Not Weaponised

==Gas==
{{See also|Russia–Ukraine gas disputes}}

Ukraine was 6th top gas importer in 2009. <ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Nafrogaz]] is the state owned gas company. Ukraine buys gas from Russia. In disputes Russia has stopped gas delivery in 2006 and 2008. In 2009 80 % of the [[European Union]] gas from Russia was delivered via Ukraine. 

==Coal==
{{See also|2008 Ukraine coal mine collapse}}

[[Zasyadko Mine]] was the biggest coal mine in 2007. 


==Electricity==
Ukraine was 8th top nuclear electricity producer in 2009.  46.7 % of domestic electricity generation was nuclear. This was 2nd top, only [[Electricity sector in France|France]] was higher.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

The largest domestic gas producer is [[UkrGasVydobuvannya]], a subsidiary of the state-owned company [[Naftogaz]]. Private gas production companies in Ukraine are [[DTEK
column3: Burisma]], Smart Energy, Poltava Petroleum Company, Geo Alliance Group, and KUB-GAS.<ref>[http://agpu.org.ua/en/association/section-member_companies/] Associations of Gas Producers of Ukraine</ref>

column1: -In 2019, Ukraine produced 20.7 billion cubic meters (bcm) of natural gas, while its annual domestic demand was 26 bcm. To satisfy domestic demand, Ukraine relies on gas imports, which totals approximately one third of its domestic demand.<ref>[https://www.kyivpost.com/business/top-4-reasons-why-ukraine-gas-production-is-so-low.html], Kiev Post: Why Uraine Gas Production is So Low</ref> To meet domestic demand, Ukraine plans to increase domestic natural gas output to 27 bcm. According to a report issued by the [[OECD]], over 70% of the domestic gas production is covered by the Naftogaz subsidiary UkrGasVydobuvannya. <ref>[http://www.oecd.org/corporate/SOE-Reform-in-the-Hydrocarbons-Sector-in-Ukraine-ENG.pdf], OECD Report on SOE Reform in the Hydrocarbons Sector in Ukraine</ref>

+In 2019, Ukraine produced 20.7 billion cubic meters (bcm) of natural gas, while its annual domestic demand was 26 bcm. To satisfy domestic demand, Ukraine relies on gas imports, which totals approximately one third of its domestic demand.<ref>[https://www.kyivpost.com/business/top-4-reasons-why-ukraine-gas-production-is-so-low.html], Kiev Post: Why Uraine Gas Production is So Low</ref> To meet domestic demand, Ukraine plans to increase domestic natural gas output to 27 bcm. According to a report issued by the [[OECD]], over 70% of the domestic gas production is covered by the Naftogaz subsidiary UkrGasVydobuvannya.<ref>[http://www.oecd.org/corporate/SOE-Reform-in-the-Hydrocarbons-Sector-in-Ukraine-ENG.pdf], OECD Report on SOE Reform in the Hydrocarbons Sector in Ukraine</ref>

'''Energy in Ukraine ''' describes [[World energy resources and consumption | energy]] and [[Electricity generation|electricity]] production, consumption and import in [[Ukraine]]. [[Energy policy of Ukraine]] will describe the [[politics of Ukraine]] related to energy more in detail. [[Electricity sector in Mexico]] is the main article of electricity in Ukraine.

Ukraine has depended on Russia for most energy supplies, especially natural gas  There was low prices for natural gas until 2009. Ukraine tries to diversify energy sources.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref>

[[File:Ukraine electricity by source 2019.png

-In 2014 total electricity production was 183 [[TWh]], of which 8 TWh was exported to Europe; 88 TWh from nuclear, 71 TWh from coal, 13 TWh from natural gas, and 9 TWh from [[hydroelectricity]]. Electricity consumption was 134 TWh after transmission losses of 20 TWh, with peak demand at about 28 [[GWe]]. In 2015 electricity production fell to about 146 TWh largely due to a fall in [[anthracite]] coal supplies caused by the [[War in Donbass]].<ref name=wnn-20170217>{{cite news

column8: title=Poroshenko: Share of nuclear power grows to 60% amid blockade of trade with Donbas

==Gas==
{{See also|Russia–Ukraine gas disputes}}

Ukraine was 6th top gas importer in 2009. <ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Nafrogaz]] is the state owned gas company. Ukraine buys gas from Russia. In disputes Russia has stopped gas delivery in 2006 and 2008. In 2009 80 % of the [[European Union]] gas from Russia was delivered via Ukraine. 

==Coal==
{{See also|2008 Ukraine coal mine collapse}}

[[Zasyadko Mine]] was the biggest coal mine in 2007. 


==Electricity==
Ukraine was 8th top nuclear electricity producer in 2009.  46.7 % of domestic electricity generation was nuclear. This was 2nd top, only [[Electricity sector in France|France]] was higher.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

'''Energy in Ukraine ''' describes [[World energy resources and consumption
column3: electricity]] production, consumption and import in [[Ukraine]]. As an industry it is part of the Fuel and Energy Complex that combines smaller industries such as power generation and distribution, coal, oil and gas mining industries as well as transportation of resources. Ukraine's geographic position and proximity to Russia explain its importance as a natural gas and petroleum liquids transit country.

column1: -Approximately 3.0 trillion cubic feet (Tcf) of natural gas flowed through Ukraine in 2013 to Austria, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Croatia, Czech Republic, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Moldova, Poland, Romania, Slovakia, and Turkey.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title = International - U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA)}}</ref>

column5: title = International - U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA)}}</ref>

column2: oil]] (which are also produced domestically) while being a net-exporter of electricity and [[coal]]. Ukraine tries to diversify energy sources.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International</ref>

column1: {{See also
==Electricity==

-In 2014 total electricity production was 183 [[TWh]], of which 8 TWh was exported to Europe; 88 TWh from nuclear, 71 TWh from coal, 13 TWh from natural gas, and 9 TWh from [[hydroelectricity]]. Electricity consumption was 134 TWh after transmission losses of 20 TWh, with peak demand at about 28 [[GWe]]. In 2015 electricity production fell to about 146 TWh largely due to a fall in [[anthracite]] coal supplies caused by the [[War in Donbass]].<ref name=wnn-20170217>{{cite news
column3: title=Poroshenko: Ukraine increasing nuclear share to 60%
column8: title=Poroshenko: Share of nuclear power grows to 60% amid blockade of trade with Donbas

+Electricity production fell from 296 TWh in 1991 to 171 TWh in 1999, then increased slowly to 195 TWh in 2007, before falling again.<ref name=wna-20170216>{{cite web
-In 2011 Ukraine joined the [[European Energy Community]], however there has been slow progress on implementing European energy regulations.<ref name=wilsoncenter-20190506>{{cite web
column3: title=Liberalizing Ukraine's Electricity Market: Benefits and Risks

column1: +In 2011 Ukraine joined the [[European Energy Community]], however there has been slow progress on implementing European energy regulations.<ref name=wilsoncenter-20190506>{{cite web
column3: title=Liberalizing Ukraine's Electricity Market: Benefits and Risks

column1: -On 1 July 2019, a new wholesale energy market was launched, intended to bring real competition in the generation market and help future integration with Europe. The change was a prerequisite for receiving European Union assistance. It led to in increased price for industrial consumers of between 14% to 28% during July. The bulk of [[Energoatom]] output is sold to the government's ""guaranteed buyer"" to keep prices more stable for domestic customers.<ref name=wilsoncenter-20190506/><ref name=kp-20190802>{{cite news

+On 1 July 2019, a new wholesale energy market was launched, intended to bring real competition in the generation market and help future integration with Europe. The change was a prerequisite for receiving European Union assistance. It led to in increased price for industrial consumers of between 14% to 28% during July. The bulk of [[Energoatom]] output is sold to the government's ""guaranteed buyer"" to keep prices more stable for domestic customers.<ref name=wilsoncenter-20190506/><ref name=kp-20190802>{{cite news

[https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/25/world/europe/ukraine-briefly-cuts-power-to-crimea-amid-dispute-with-russia-over-nato.html?_r=0 Ukraine Briefly Cuts Power to Crimea Amid Feud With Russia Over NATO], [[New York Times]] (DEC. 24, 2014)

column1: === Renewable energy ===
{{main

In 2017 Climate News Network reported that Chinese companies plan to spend $1bn in a solar power park in the nuclear disaster area in Ukraine.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/jan/12/solar-power-to-rise-from-chernobyls-nuclear-ashes Solar power to rise from Chernobyl's nuclear ashes] Guardian 12 January 2017</ref>
==Finance==

-Ukraine signed a loan agreement in-principle for $3.65 billion with the [[China Development Bank]] in 2012, during President [[Viktor Yanukovich]]'s term of office, contingent on the development of agreed development projects in the coal and gas sectors. However, by April 2017 Ukraine had not agreed any suitable projects due to a ""lack of convergence in the positions of [Uglesintezgaz] and the energy ministry"".<ref name=reuters-20170414>{{cite news
column3: title=Ukraine could miss out on up to $3.65 billion of China energy loans

'''Energy in Ukraine ''' describes [[World energy resources and consumption | energy]] and [[Electricity generation|electricity]] production, consumption and import in [[Ukraine]]. [[Energy policy of Ukraine]] will describe the [[politics of Ukraine]] related to energy more in detail. [[Electricity sector in Mexico]] is the main article of electricity in Ukraine.

Ukraine has depended on Russia for most energy supplies, especially natural gas  There was low prices for natural gas until 2009. Ukraine tries to diversify energy sources.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref>

column1: **Weaponised**. The revision emphasizes Ukraine's reliance on Russia for energy supplies and introduces the topic of corruption, which can be interpreted as a critique of governance in Ukraine. This framing may serve to highlight vulnerabilities in Ukraine's energy independence and governance, potentially aligning with narratives that question Ukraine's legitimacy and stability in the context of its relationship with Russia.",Weaponised

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

'''Energy in Ukraine ''' describes [[World energy resources and consumption | energy]] and [[Electricity generation|electricity]] production, consumption and import in [[Ukraine]]. [[Energy policy of Ukraine]] will describe the [[politics of Ukraine]] related to energy more in detail. [[Electricity sector in Mexico]] is the main article of electricity in Ukraine.

Ukraine has depended on Russia for most energy supplies, especially natural gas  There was low prices for natural gas until 2009. Ukraine tries to diversify energy sources.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref>

==Gas==
{{See also|Russia–Ukraine gas disputes}}

Ukraine was 6th top gas importer in 2009. <ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Nafrogaz]] is the state owned gas company. Ukraine buys gas from Russia. In disputes Russia has stopped gas delivery in 2006 and 2008. In 2009 80 % of the [[European Union]] gas from Russia was delivered via Ukraine. 

==Coal==
{{See also|2008 Ukraine coal mine collapse}}

[[Zasyadko Mine]] was the biggest coal mine in 2007. 


==Electricity==
Ukraine was 8th top nuclear electricity producer in 2009.  46.7 % of domestic electricity generation was nuclear. This was 2nd top, only [[Electricity sector in France|France]] was higher.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

[[File:Perovosolarstation.jpg
-'''Energy in Ukraine ''' describes [[World energy resources and consumption
column3: electricity]] production, consumption and import in [[Ukraine]]. As an industry it is part of the Fuel and Energy Complex that combines smaller industries such as power generation and distribution, coal, oil and gas mining industries as well as transportation of resources. Ukraine's geographic position and proximity to Russia explain its importance as a natural gas and petroleum liquids transit country.

column1: +'''Energy in Ukraine '''describes [[World energy resources and consumption
column3: electricity]] production, consumption and imports. [[Ukraine]] is a major producer of energy, the majority being [[nuclear]], [[natural gas]], and [[coal]]. Since 2015, investing in renewable energy has been a priority in the sector. The government's goal is renewable energy to account 25% of its domestic production by 2035. <ref>https://www.rferl.org/a/can-renewable-power-reenergize-ukraine-/30228294.html, RFE/RE (2019), Can Renewable Power Reenergize Ukraine?</ref>

column1: -Approximately 3.0 trillion cubic feet (Tcf) of natural gas flowed through Ukraine in 2013 to Austria, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Croatia, Czech Republic, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Moldova, Poland, Romania, Slovakia, and Turkey.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title = International - U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA)}}</ref>

column1: +Ukraine is a transit country for the supply of oil and natural gas from Russia to Europe. Approximately 3.0 trillion cubic feet (Tcf) of natural gas flowed through Ukraine in 2013 to Austria, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Croatia, Czech Republic, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Moldova, Poland, Romania, Slovakia, and Turkey.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title = International - U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA)}}</ref>

column1: -Ukraine depends on [[Russia]] for its supplies of [[natural gas]] and [[petroleum
column2: oil]] (which are also produced domestically) while being a net-exporter of electricity and [[coal]]. Ukraine tries to diversify energy sources.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International</ref>

column1: +Ukraine is a part of the EU4Energy Program, a regionally-focused evidence-based policy making for the energy sector program implemented by the [[International Energy Agency]] and the [[European Union]], along with the [[Energy Community]] and the [[Energy Charter Treaty
column2: Energy Charter]], which concentrates on the eleven countries in the [[Caucasus]], [[Eastern Europe]] and [[Central Asia]].<ref>https://www.iea.org/countries/Ukraine, Ukraine, International Energy Agency.</ref>

column1: == Overview ==
{{see also

In 2017 Climate News Network reported that Chinese companies plan to spend $1bn in a solar power park in the nuclear disaster area in Ukraine.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/jan/12/solar-power-to-rise-from-chernobyls-nuclear-ashes Solar power to rise from Chernobyl's nuclear ashes] Guardian 12 January 2017</ref>

+From to 2018 to 2019, solar energy production has grown from 948 MW to 2640 MW, while wind production has from 515 MW to 776 MW.<ref>https://www.slideshare.net/NKREKP/2019-152188845?ref=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nerc.gov.ua%2F%3Fnews&fbclid=IwAR2NGKRrIpJ-7KSFy8QQqUvIMMCeOgQAwINf74iwFnB7bWtkanrKes7KgJU, NERC Ukraine (2019), Overview of Renewable Energy Sector, National Energy and Utilities Regulatory Commission.</ref>
==Finance==

Ukraine signed a loan agreement in-principle for $3.65 billion with the [[China Development Bank]] in 2012, during President [[Viktor Yanukovich]]'s term of office, contingent on the development of agreed development projects in the coal and gas sectors. However, by April 2017 Ukraine had not agreed any suitable projects due to a ""lack of convergence in the positions of [Uglesintezgaz] and the energy ministry"".<ref name=reuters-20170414>{{cite news
column3: title=Ukraine could miss out on up to $3.65 billion of China energy loans

column1: ",Cleaned up old data and updated with new content,Aj001986,2020-05-08T20:54:18Z,"The change made is a combination of rephrasing and adding new content. Specifically, the editor rephrased sections about energy production and consumption in Ukraine, emphasizing Ukraine's role as a major energy producer and its goals for renewable energy. Additionally, new information was added regarding Ukraine's participation in the EU4Energy Program and statistics on solar and wind energy production growth.

Not Weaponised. The changes focus on factual updates and improvements in clarity regarding Ukraine's energy sector without employing weaponised narratives or terms that could be seen as politically charged.",Not Weaponised

column1: On 1 July 2019, a new wholesale energy market was launched, intended to bring real competition in the generation market and help future integration with Europe. The change was a prerequisite for receiving European Union assistance. It led to in increased price for industrial consumers of between 14% to 28% during July. The bulk of [[Energoatom]] output is sold to the government's ""guaranteed buyer"" to keep prices more stable for domestic customers.<ref name=wilsoncenter-20190506/><ref name=kp-20190802>{{cite news

|}

==Gas==
{{See also|Russia–Ukraine gas disputes}}

Ukraine was 6th top gas importer in 2009. <ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Nafrogaz]] is the state owned gas company. Ukraine buys gas from Russia. In disputes Russia has stopped gas delivery in 2006 and 2008. In 2009 80 % of the [[European Union]] gas from Russia was delivered via Ukraine. 

==Coal==
{{See also|2008 Ukraine coal mine collapse}}

[[Zasyadko Mine]] was the biggest coal mine in 2007. 


==Electricity==
Ukraine was 8th top nuclear electricity producer in 2009.  46.7 % of domestic electricity generation was nuclear. This was 2nd top, only [[Electricity sector in France|France]] was higher.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

{{Commonscat|Energy in Ukraine }}

{{Europe topic|Energy policy of}}

[[Category:Energy in Ukraine| *]]
{{DEFAULTSORT: Ukraine}},"---

In 2019, Ukraine produced 20.7 billion cubic meters (bcm) of natural gas, while its annual domestic demand was 26 bcm. To satisfy domestic demand, Ukraine relies on gas imports, which totals approximately one third of its domestic demand.<ref>[https://www.kyivpost.com/business/top-4-reasons-why-ukraine-gas-production-is-so-low.html], Kiev Post: Why Uraine Gas Production is So Low</ref> To meet domestic demand, Ukraine plans to increase domestic natural gas output to 27 bcm. According to a report issued by the [[OECD]], over 70% of the domestic gas production is covered by the Naftogaz subsidiary UkrGasVydobuvannya.<ref>[http://www.oecd.org/corporate/SOE-Reform-in-the-Hydrocarbons-Sector-in-Ukraine-ENG.pdf], OECD Report on SOE Reform in the Hydrocarbons Sector in Ukraine</ref>

=== Nuclear power ===

column1: [[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company founded in 1996. It has about 38,000 employees.

Ukraine signed a loan agreement in-principle for $3.65 billion with the [[China Development Bank]] in 2012, during President [[Viktor Yanukovich]]'s term of office, contingent on the development of agreed development projects in the coal and gas sectors. However, by April 2017 Ukraine had not agreed any suitable projects due to a ""lack of convergence in the positions of [Uglesintezgaz] and the energy ministry"".<ref name=reuters-20170414>{{cite news
column3: title=Ukraine could miss out on up to $3.65 billion of China energy loans

'''Energy in Ukraine ''' describes [[World energy resources and consumption | energy]] and [[Electricity generation|electricity]] production, consumption and import in [[Ukraine]]. [[Energy policy of Ukraine]] will describe the [[politics of Ukraine]] related to energy more in detail. [[Electricity sector in Mexico]] is the main article of electricity in Ukraine.

Ukraine has depended on Russia for most energy supplies, especially natural gas  There was low prices for natural gas until 2009. Ukraine tries to diversify energy sources.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref>

==Gas==
{{See also|Russia–Ukraine gas disputes}}

Ukraine was 6th top gas importer in 2009. <ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Nafrogaz]] is the state owned gas company. Ukraine buys gas from Russia. In disputes Russia has stopped gas delivery in 2006 and 2008. In 2009 80 % of the [[European Union]] gas from Russia was delivered via Ukraine. 

==Coal==
{{See also|2008 Ukraine coal mine collapse}}

[[Zasyadko Mine]] was the biggest coal mine in 2007. 


==Electricity==
Ukraine was 8th top nuclear electricity producer in 2009.  46.7 % of domestic electricity generation was nuclear. This was 2nd top, only [[Electricity sector in France|France]] was higher.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

==Finance==

Ukraine signed a loan agreement in-principle for $3.65 billion with the [[China Development Bank]] in 2012, during President [[Viktor Yanukovich]]'s term of office, contingent on the development of agreed development projects in the coal and gas sectors. However, by April 2017 Ukraine had not agreed any suitable projects due to a ""lack of convergence in the positions of [Uglesintezgaz] and the energy ministry"".<ref name=reuters-20170414>{{cite news
column3: title=Ukraine could miss out on up to $3.65 billion of China energy loans

+'''Energy in Ukraine ''' describes [[World energy resources and consumption
column3: electricity]] production, consumption and import in [[Ukraine]]. As an industry it is part of the Fuel and Energy Complex that combines smaller industries such as power generation and distribution, coal, oil and gas mining industries as well as transportation of resources. Ukraine's geographic position and proximity to Russia explain its importance as a natural gas and petroleum liquids transit country.

column1: +Approximately 3.0 trillion cubic feet (Tcf) of natural gas flowed through Ukraine in 2013 to Austria, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Croatia, Czech Republic, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Moldova, Poland, Romania, Slovakia, and Turkey.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title = International - U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA)}}</ref>

column1: +Ukraine depends on [[Russia]] for its supplies of [[natural gas]] and [[petroleum
column2: oil]] (which are also produced domestically) while being a net-exporter of electricity and [[coal]]. Ukraine tries to diversify energy sources.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International</ref>

column1: +Ukraine was the 6th highest importer of natural gas in 2009.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref> Ukraine stopped buying gas from Russia in 2015 due to the Russian presence in eastern Ukraine.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Naftogaz open letter: a year without gas imports from Russia
column7: accessdate=31 August 2018}}</ref> In disputes Russia has stopped gas delivery in 2006 and 2008. In 2009 80% of the [[European Union]] gas from Russia was delivered via Ukraine.

column1: +The largest domestic gas producer is [[UkrGasVydobuvannya]], a subsidiary of the state-owned company [[Naftogaz]]. Private gas production companies in Ukraine are [[DTEK
column3: Burisma]], Smart Energy, Poltava Petroleum Company, Geo Alliance Group, and KUB-GAS.<ref>[http://agpu.org.ua/en/association/section-member_companies/] Associations of Gas Producers of Ukraine</ref>

column1: +In 2019, Ukraine produced 20.7 billion cubic meters (bcm) of natural gas, while its annual domestic demand was 26 bcm. To satisfy domestic demand, Ukraine relies on gas imports, which totals approximately one third of its domestic demand.<ref>[https://www.kyivpost.com/business/top-4-reasons-why-ukraine-gas-production-is-so-low.html], Kiev Post: Why Uraine Gas Production is So Low</ref> To meet domestic demand, Ukraine plans to increase domestic natural gas output to 27 bcm. According to a report issued by the [[OECD]], over 70% of the domestic gas production is covered by the Naftogaz subsidiary UkrGasVydobuvannya. <ref>[http://www.oecd.org/corporate/SOE-Reform-in-the-Hydrocarbons-Sector-in-Ukraine-ENG.pdf], OECD Report on SOE Reform in the Hydrocarbons Sector in Ukraine</ref>
+==Coal==
+{{See also
+==Electricity==

+In 2014 total electricity production was 183 [[TWh]], of which 8 TWh was exported to Europe; 88 TWh from nuclear, 71 TWh from coal, 13 TWh from natural gas, and 9 TWh from [[hydroelectricity]]. Electricity consumption was 134 TWh after transmission losses of 20 TWh, with peak demand at about 28 [[GWe]]. In 2015 electricity production fell to about 146 TWh largely due to a fall in [[anthracite]] coal supplies caused by the [[War in Donbass]].<ref name=wnn-20170217>{{cite news
column3: title=Poroshenko: Ukraine increasing nuclear share to 60%
column8: title=Poroshenko: Share of nuclear power grows to 60% amid blockade of trade with Donbas

column1: +Electricity production fell from 296 TWh in 1991 to 171 TWh in 1999, then increased slowly to 195 TWh in 2007, before falling again.<ref name=wna-20170216>{{cite web
+In 2011 Ukraine joined the [[European Energy Community]], however there has been slow progress on implementing European energy regulations.<ref name=wilsoncenter-20190506>{{cite web
column3: title=Liberalizing Ukraine's Electricity Market: Benefits and Risks

column1: +On 1 July 2019, a new wholesale energy market was launched, intended to bring real competition in the generation market and help future integration with Europe. The change was a prerequisite for receiving European Union assistance. It led to in increased price for industrial consumers of between 14% to 28% during July. The bulk of [[Energoatom]] output is sold to the government's ""guaranteed buyer"" to keep prices more stable for domestic customers.<ref name=wilsoncenter-20190506/><ref name=kp-20190802>{{cite news
+=== Nuclear power ===
+[[File:РАЭС. Украина.JPG
+{{see also
+Ukraine was 8th top nuclear electricity producer in 2009. 46.7% of domestic electricity generation was nuclear. This was the 2nd largest share, only [[Electricity sector in France
column2: France]] was higher.<ref name=IEA2012>[http://www.iea.org/publications/freepublications/publication/Ukraine2012_free.pdf p.187 of the IEA 2010 Publication on Ukrainian Energy]</ref> The largest nuclear power plant in Europe is in Ukraine.

column1: +[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company founded in 1996. It has about 38,000 employees.
+The 1986 [[Chernobyl disaster]] in Northern Ukraine was the world's most severe nuclear accident.
+[[Coal in Ukraine#Coal production
column2:
Lack of coal for Ukraine's coal-fired power stations]] due to the [[War in Donbass]] and a shut down one of the six reactors of the [[Zaporizhia Nuclear Power Plant]] lead to rolling blackouts throughout [[Ukraine]] from early till late December 2014.[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/ukraine-turns-off-reactor-at-nuclear-plant-after-accident-9947540.html Ukraine turns off reactor at its most powerful nuclear plant after 'accident'], [[The Independent]] (28 December 2014)
[https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/25/world/europe/ukraine-briefly-cuts-power-to-crimea-amid-dispute-with-russia-over-nato.html?_r=0 Ukraine Briefly Cuts Power to Crimea Amid Feud With Russia Over NATO], [[New York Times]] (DEC. 24, 2014)
[http://itar-tass.com/en/economy/770172 Coal import to help avoid rolling blackouts in Ukraine—energy minister], [[ITAR-TASS]] (December 31, 2014)
[http://mashable.com/2014/12/03/ukraine-nuclear-plant-accident/ Rolling blackouts in Ukraine after nuclear plant accident], [[Mashable]] (Dec 03, 2014)
[https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-12-31/ukraine-to-import-coal-from-far-away-as-war-curtails-mines.html Ukraine to Import Coal From ‘Far Away’ as War Curtails Mines], [[Bloomberg News]] (Dec 31, 2014)

column1: +In 2018 [[Energoatom]] stated that electricity prices were too low to cover the cost of new [[nuclear fuel]], and called for a price increase.<ref name=wnn-20180319>{{cite news
column3: title=Energoatom counts cost of regulatory changes

column1: +=== Renewable energy ===
+{{main
+{{see also

+In 2017 Climate News Network reported that Chinese companies plan to spend $1bn in a solar power park in the nuclear disaster area in Ukraine.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/jan/12/solar-power-to-rise-from-chernobyls-nuclear-ashes Solar power to rise from Chernobyl's nuclear ashes] Guardian 12 January 2017</ref>
+==Finance==

+Ukraine signed a loan agreement in-principle for $3.65 billion with the [[China Development Bank]] in 2012, during President [[Viktor Yanukovich]]'s term of office, contingent on the development of agreed development projects in the coal and gas sectors. However, by April 2017 Ukraine had not agreed any suitable projects due to a ""lack of convergence in the positions of [Uglesintezgaz] and the energy ministry"".<ref name=reuters-20170414>{{cite news
column3: title=Ukraine could miss out on up to $3.65 billion of China energy loans

column1: +==Corruption==
+[[Corruption in Ukraine
column2: Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=""TI2011""/> Ukraine gets gas from [[Gazprom]] via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes.<ref>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/59374/951162/TI_PRT_2011_report_FINAL_EN.pdf 2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

column1: +In 2015 corruption allegations were made against Energoatom, Ukraine's [[Nuclear power in Ukraine
column2: nuclear power operator]], with concerns raised by Prime Minister [[Arseniy Yatsenyuk]].<ref name=wnn-20150812>{{cite news
column4: title=Energoatom chief recalls highs and lows of first half-year
column7: accessdate=16 June 2016}}</ref> In March 2016, Energoatom's assets and bank accounts were frozen by Ukrainian courts over allegedly unpaid debts, against which Energoatom is appealing.<ref name=nei-20160607>{{cite news
column14: title=Ex-head of Energoatom Derkach claims worst situation in sector in 25 years

column1: Not Weaponised. The changes focus on factual information regarding energy resources and do not employ language or narratives that could be construed as weaponizing cultural heritage.",Not Weaponised

'''Energy in Ukraine ''' describes [[World energy resources and consumption | energy]] and [[Electricity generation|electricity]] production, consumption and import in [[Ukraine]]. [[Energy policy of Ukraine]] will describe the [[politics of Ukraine]] related to energy more in detail. [[Electricity sector in Mexico]] is the main article of electricity in Ukraine.

Ukraine has depended on Russia for most energy supplies, especially natural gas  There was low prices for natural gas until 2009. Ukraine tries to diversify energy sources.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref>

==Gas==
{{See also|Russia–Ukraine gas disputes}}

Ukraine was 6th top gas importer in 2009. <ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Nafrogaz]] is the state owned gas company. Ukraine buys gas from Russia. In disputes Russia has stopped gas delivery in 2006 and 2008. In 2009 80 % of the [[European Union]] gas from Russia was delivered via Ukraine. 

==Coal==
{{See also|2008 Ukraine coal mine collapse}}

[[Zasyadko Mine]] was the biggest coal mine in 2007. 


==Electricity==
Ukraine was 8th top nuclear electricity producer in 2009.  46.7 % of domestic electricity generation was nuclear. This was 2nd top, only [[Electricity sector in France|France]] was higher.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

==Gas==
{{See also|Russia–Ukraine gas disputes}}

Ukraine was 6th top gas importer in 2009. <ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Nafrogaz]] is the state owned gas company. Ukraine buys gas from Russia. In disputes Russia has stopped gas delivery in 2006 and 2008. In 2009 80 % of the [[European Union]] gas from Russia was delivered via Ukraine. 

==Coal==
{{See also|2008 Ukraine coal mine collapse}}

[[Zasyadko Mine]] was the biggest coal mine in 2007. 


==Electricity==
Ukraine was 8th top nuclear electricity producer in 2009.  46.7 % of domestic electricity generation was nuclear. This was 2nd top, only [[Electricity sector in France|France]] was higher.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

{{DEFAULTSORT: Ukraine}},"---

On 1 July 2019, a new wholesale energy market was launched, intended to bring real competition in the generation market and help future integration with Europe. The change was a prerequisite for receiving European Union assistance. It led to in increased price for industrial consumers of between 14% to 28% during July. The bulk of [[Energoatom]] output is sold to the government's ""guaranteed buyer"" to keep prices more stable for domestic customers.<ref name=wilsoncenter-20190506/><ref name=kp-20190802>{{cite news

'''Energy in Ukraine ''' describes [[World energy resources and consumption | energy]] and [[Electricity generation|electricity]] production, consumption and import in [[Ukraine]]. [[Energy policy of Ukraine]] will describe the [[politics of Ukraine]] related to energy more in detail. [[Electricity sector in Mexico]] is the main article of electricity in Ukraine.

Ukraine has depended on Russia for most energy supplies, especially natural gas  There was low prices for natural gas until 2009. Ukraine tries to diversify energy sources.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref>

==Gas==
{{See also|Russia–Ukraine gas disputes}}

Ukraine was 6th top gas importer in 2009. <ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Nafrogaz]] is the state owned gas company. Ukraine buys gas from Russia. In disputes Russia has stopped gas delivery in 2006 and 2008. In 2009 80 % of the [[European Union]] gas from Russia was delivered via Ukraine. 

==Coal==
{{See also|2008 Ukraine coal mine collapse}}

[[Zasyadko Mine]] was the biggest coal mine in 2007. 


==Electricity==
Ukraine was 8th top nuclear electricity producer in 2009.  46.7 % of domestic electricity generation was nuclear. This was 2nd top, only [[Electricity sector in France|France]] was higher.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

'''Energy in Ukraine ''' describes [[World energy resources and consumption | energy]] and [[Electricity generation|electricity]] production, consumption and import in [[Ukraine]]. [[Energy policy of Ukraine]] will describe the [[politics of Ukraine]] related to energy more in detail. [[Electricity sector in Mexico]] is the main article of electricity in Ukraine.

Ukraine has depended on Russia for most energy supplies, especially natural gas  There was low prices for natural gas until 2009. Ukraine tries to diversify energy sources.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref>

==Gas==
{{See also|Russia–Ukraine gas disputes}}

Ukraine was 6th top gas importer in 2009. <ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Nafrogaz]] is the state owned gas company. Ukraine buys gas from Russia. In disputes Russia has stopped gas delivery in 2006 and 2008. In 2009 80 % of the [[European Union]] gas from Russia was delivered via Ukraine. 

==Coal==
{{See also|2008 Ukraine coal mine collapse}}

[[Zasyadko Mine]] was the biggest coal mine in 2007. 


==Electricity==
Ukraine was 8th top nuclear electricity producer in 2009.  46.7 % of domestic electricity generation was nuclear. This was 2nd top, only [[Electricity sector in France|France]] was higher.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

'''Energy in Ukraine ''' describes [[World energy resources and consumption | energy]] and [[Electricity generation|electricity]] production, consumption and import in [[Ukraine]]. [[Energy policy of Ukraine]] will describe the [[politics of Ukraine]] related to energy more in detail. [[Electricity sector in Mexico]] is the main article of electricity in Ukraine.

Ukraine has depended on Russia for most energy supplies, especially natural gas  There was low prices for natural gas until 2009. Ukraine tries to diversify energy sources.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref>

'''Energy in Ukraine ''' describes [[World energy resources and consumption | energy]] and [[Electricity generation|electricity]] production, consumption and import in [[Ukraine]]. [[Energy policy of Ukraine]] will describe the [[politics of Ukraine]] related to energy more in detail. [[Electricity sector in Mexico]] is the main article of electricity in Ukraine.

Ukraine has depended on Russia for most energy supplies, especially natural gas  There was low prices for natural gas until 2009. Ukraine tries to diversify energy sources.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref>

==Gas==
{{See also|Russia–Ukraine gas disputes}}

Ukraine was 6th top gas importer in 2009. <ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Nafrogaz]] is the state owned gas company. Ukraine buys gas from Russia. In disputes Russia has stopped gas delivery in 2006 and 2008. In 2009 80 % of the [[European Union]] gas from Russia was delivered via Ukraine. 

==Coal==
{{See also|2008 Ukraine coal mine collapse}}

[[Zasyadko Mine]] was the biggest coal mine in 2007. 


==Electricity==
Ukraine was 8th top nuclear electricity producer in 2009.  46.7 % of domestic electricity generation was nuclear. This was 2nd top, only [[Electricity sector in France|France]] was higher.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

column1: -Ukraine was the 6th highest importer of natural gas in 2009.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref> Ukraine stopped buying gas from Russia in 2015 due to the Russian presence in eastern Ukraine.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Naftogaz open letter: a year without gas imports from Russia
column5: access-date=31 August 2018}}</ref> In disputes Russia has stopped gas delivery in 2006 and 2008. In 2009 80% of the [[European Union]] gas from Russia was delivered via Ukraine.

column1: -The largest domestic gas producer is [[UkrGasVydobuvannya]], a subsidiary of the state-owned company [[Naftogaz]]. Private gas production companies in Ukraine are [[DTEK
column3: Burisma]], Smart Energy, Poltava Petroleum Company, Geo Alliance Group, and KUB-GAS.<ref>[http://agpu.org.ua/en/association/section-member_companies/] {{Webarchive
column5: date=2020-09-29 }} Associations of Gas Producers of Ukraine</ref>

column1: -In 2019, Ukraine produced 20.7 billion cubic meters (bcm) of natural gas, while its annual domestic demand was 26 bcm. To satisfy domestic demand, Ukraine relies on gas imports, which totals approximately one third of its domestic demand.<ref>[https://www.kyivpost.com/business/top-4-reasons-why-ukraine-gas-production-is-so-low.html], Kiev Post: Why Uraine Gas Production is So Low</ref> To meet domestic demand, Ukraine plans to increase domestic natural gas output to 27 bcm. According to a report issued by the [[OECD]], over 70% of the domestic gas production is covered by the Naftogaz subsidiary UkrGasVydobuvannya.<ref>[http://www.oecd.org/corporate/SOE-Reform-in-the-Hydrocarbons-Sector-in-Ukraine-ENG.pdf], OECD Report on SOE Reform in the Hydrocarbons Sector in Ukraine</ref>

==Gas==
{{See also|Russia–Ukraine gas disputes}}

Ukraine was 6th top gas importer in 2009. <ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Nafrogaz]] is the state owned gas company. Ukraine buys gas from Russia. In disputes Russia has stopped gas delivery in 2006 and 2008. In 2009 80 % of the [[European Union]] gas from Russia was delivered via Ukraine. 

==Coal==
{{See also|2008 Ukraine coal mine collapse}}

[[Zasyadko Mine]] was the biggest coal mine in 2007. 


==Electricity==
Ukraine was 8th top nuclear electricity producer in 2009.  46.7 % of domestic electricity generation was nuclear. This was 2nd top, only [[Electricity sector in France|France]] was higher.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

{{DEFAULTSORT: Ukraine}},"---

On 1 July 2019, a new wholesale energy market was launched, intended to bring real competition in the generation market and help future integration with Europe. The change was a prerequisite for receiving European Union assistance. It led to in increased price for industrial consumers of between 14% to 28% during July. The bulk of [[Energoatom]] output is sold to the government's ""guaranteed buyer"" to keep prices more stable for domestic customers.<ref name=wilsoncenter-20190506/><ref name=kp-20190802>{{cite news
=== Nuclear power ===
-In 2008 [[Westinghouse Electric Company]] won a five-year contract selling nuclear fuel to three Ukrainian reactors starting in 2011.<ref>{{cite web
column2: title=Westinghouse Wins Contract to Provide Fuel Supplies to Ukraine
column10: format=press release}}</ref> Following [[Euromaidan]] then President [[Viktor Yanukovych]] introduced a ban on [[Rosatom]] nuclear fuel shipments to Europe via Ukraine, which was in effect from 28 January until 6 March 2014.<ref>{{cite news
column12: title=Russia says restarts nuclear fuel transit to Europe via Ukraine
column18: archive-date=16 October 2015}}</ref> By 2016, Russia's share was down to 55 percent, [[Westinghouse Electric Company
column19: Westinghouse]] supplying nuclear fuel for six of Ukraine's [[VVER-1000]] nuclear reactors.<ref name=""enimp"">{{cite web
column23: title=American coal miners undermine Putin's energy weapon against Ukraine
column30: publisher=[[Newsweek
column31: Newsweek Media Group]]}}</ref> After the Russian annexation of Crimea in April 2014, the National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine [[Energoatom]] and Westinghouse extended the contract for fuel deliveries through 2020.<ref name="":1"" />{{excerpt

column1: +{{excerpt
=== Renewable energy ===

'''Energy in Ukraine ''' describes [[World energy resources and consumption | energy]] and [[Electricity generation|electricity]] production, consumption and import in [[Ukraine]]. [[Energy policy of Ukraine]] will describe the [[politics of Ukraine]] related to energy more in detail. [[Electricity sector in Mexico]] is the main article of electricity in Ukraine.

Ukraine has depended on Russia for most energy supplies, especially natural gas  There was low prices for natural gas until 2009. Ukraine tries to diversify energy sources.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref>

==Gas==
{{See also|Russia–Ukraine gas disputes}}

Ukraine was 6th top gas importer in 2009. <ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Nafrogaz]] is the state owned gas company. Ukraine buys gas from Russia. In disputes Russia has stopped gas delivery in 2006 and 2008. In 2009 80 % of the [[European Union]] gas from Russia was delivered via Ukraine. 

==Coal==
{{See also|2008 Ukraine coal mine collapse}}

[[Zasyadko Mine]] was the biggest coal mine in 2007. 


==Electricity==
Ukraine was 8th top nuclear electricity producer in 2009.  46.7 % of domestic electricity generation was nuclear. This was 2nd top, only [[Electricity sector in France|France]] was higher.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

About half of [[electricity generation]] is nuclear and a quarter coal.<ref name="":0"" /> The largest [[nuclear power plant]] in Europe, the [[Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant]], is located in Ukraine. Until the 2010s all of Ukraine's nuclear fuel came from Russia, but now most does not.<ref name="":1"">{{cite web

The addition of ""Although gas transit is declining"" introduces a narrative that emphasizes a negative trend regarding gas transit, which could be interpreted as a subtle framing of the situation to highlight issues related to energy dependency and geopolitical tensions, potentially weaponizing the context of energy resources in the ongoing conflict.",Weaponised

'''Energy in Ukraine ''' describes [[World energy resources and consumption | energy]] and [[Electricity generation|electricity]] production, consumption and import in [[Ukraine]]. [[Energy policy of Ukraine]] will describe the [[politics of Ukraine]] related to energy more in detail. [[Electricity sector in Mexico]] is the main article of electricity in Ukraine.

Ukraine has depended on Russia for most energy supplies, especially natural gas  There was low prices for natural gas until 2009. Ukraine tries to diversify energy sources.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref>

==References==
<references/>

{{Europe topic|Energy in}}
{{Europe topic|Energy policy of}}

[[Category:Energy in Ukraine| *]]
{{DEFAULTSORT: Ukraine}},"---

On 1 July 2019, a new wholesale energy market was launched, intended to bring real competition in the generation market and help future integration with Europe. The change was a prerequisite for receiving European Union assistance. It led to in increased price for industrial consumers of between 14% to 28% during July. The bulk of [[Energoatom]] output is sold to the government's ""guaranteed buyer"" to keep prices more stable for domestic customers.<ref name=wilsoncenter-20190506/><ref name=kp-20190802>{{cite news
-Since 2017 Ukraine sought to divest itself of dependency on the Russian synchronised system [[IPS/UPS
column2: UPS]] and instead connect westwards with the [[Synchronous grid of Continental Europe]], thereby participating in European electricity markets.<ref name=swp-20211124>{{cite web
column4: title=Connecting Ukraine to Europe’s Electricity Grid
column10: title=Explainer: Europe and Ukraine's plan to link power grids
column18: access-date=1 April 2022}}</ref> Power lines existed coupling the country to the grids of neighbouring Poland, Romania, Slovakia and Hungary, but were de-energised. A necessary prerequisite of Ukrainian integration was the country to successfully demonstrate it was capable of running in a islanded manner, maintaining satisfactory control of its own frequency. To do that would require disconnection from the UPS grid, and a date of 24 February 2022 was set. This proved to be the date [[2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine
column19: Russia invaded Ukraine]], but the disconnection nonetheless proceeded to schedule. Ukraine placed an urgent request to synchronise with the European grid to [[ENTSO-E]], the European collective of [[transmission system operator]]s of which it was a member, and on 16 March 2022 the western circuits were energised, bringing both Ukraine and Moldova, which is coupled to the Ukrainian grid, into the European synchronised grid.<ref>{{cite web
column21: title=Continental Europe successful synchronisation with Ukraine and Moldova power systems
column25: title=Ukraine joins European power grid, ending its dependence on Russia
column30: issue=16 March 2022
column32: archive-date=16 March 2022}}</ref> On 16 March 2022 a trial synchronisation started of the Ukraine and Moldova grid with the European grid.<ref name=entsoe-20220316>{{cite web
column34: title=Continental Europe successful synchronisation with Ukraine and Moldova power systems

[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

==Gas==
{{See also|Russia–Ukraine gas disputes}}

Ukraine was 6th top gas importer in 2009. <ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Nafrogaz]] is the state owned gas company. Ukraine buys gas from Russia. In disputes Russia has stopped gas delivery in 2006 and 2008. In 2009 80 % of the [[European Union]] gas from Russia was delivered via Ukraine. 

==Coal==
{{See also|2008 Ukraine coal mine collapse}}

[[Zasyadko Mine]] was the biggest coal mine in 2007. 


==Electricity==
Ukraine was 8th top nuclear electricity producer in 2009.  46.7 % of domestic electricity generation was nuclear. This was 2nd top, only [[Electricity sector in France|France]] was higher.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

{{DEFAULTSORT: Ukraine}},"---

On 1 July 2019, a new wholesale energy market was launched, intended to bring real competition in the generation market and help future integration with Europe. The change was a prerequisite for receiving European Union assistance. It led to in increased price for industrial consumers of between 14% to 28% during July. The bulk of [[Energoatom]] output is sold to the government's ""guaranteed buyer"" to keep prices more stable for domestic customers.<ref name=wilsoncenter-20190506/><ref name=kp-20190802>{{cite news
===Grid synchronisation with Europe===
-Since 2017 Ukraine sought to divest itself of dependency on the Russian synchronised system [[IPS/UPS
column2: UPS]] and instead connect westwards with the [[Synchronous grid of Continental Europe]], thereby participating in European electricity markets.<ref name=swp-20211124>{{cite web
column4: title=Connecting Ukraine to Europe’s Electricity Grid
column10: title=Explainer: Europe and Ukraine's plan to link power grids
column18: access-date=1 April 2022}}</ref> Power lines existed coupling the country to the grids of neighbouring Poland, Romania, Slovakia and Hungary, but were de-energised.

column1: +Since 2017 Ukraine sought to divest itself of dependency on the Russian synchronised system [[IPS/UPS
column2: UPS]] (Unified Power System of Russia) and instead connect westwards with the [[Synchronous grid of Continental Europe]], thereby participating in European electricity markets.<ref name=swp-20211124>{{cite web
column4: title=Connecting Ukraine to Europe’s Electricity Grid
column10: title=Explainer: Europe and Ukraine's plan to link power grids
column18: access-date=1 April 2022}}</ref> Power lines existed coupling the country to the grids of neighbouring Poland, Romania, Slovakia and Hungary, but were de-energised.

column1: A necessary prerequisite of Ukrainian integration was the country to successfully demonstrate it was capable of running in a islanded manner, maintaining satisfactory control of its own frequency. To do that would require disconnection from the UPS grid, and a date of 24 February 2022 was set. This proved to be the date [[2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine
column2: Russia invaded Ukraine]], but the disconnection nonetheless proceeded to schedule. Ukraine placed an urgent request to synchronise with the European grid to [[ENTSO-E]], the European collective of [[transmission system operator]]s of which it was a member, and on 16 March 2022 the western circuits were energised, bringing both Ukraine and Moldova, which is coupled to the Ukrainian grid, into the European synchronised grid.<ref name=entsoe-20220316>{{cite web
column4: title=Continental Europe successful synchronisation with Ukraine and Moldova power systems
column8: title=Ukraine joins European power grid, ending its dependence on Russia
column15: archive-date=16 March 2022}}</ref> On 16 March 2022 a trial synchronisation started of the Ukraine and Moldova grid with the European grid.<ref name=entsoe-20220316/>

column1: ",/* Grid synchronisation with Europe */,97.122.180.75,2022-05-01T21:28:13Z,"Changed ""Russian synchronised system"" to ""Russian synchronised system (Unified Power System of Russia)"".
Not Weaponised. The change provides clarification by adding the full name of the Russian system, which does not introduce any weaponised language or narratives.",Not Weaponised

==Finance==

Ukraine signed a loan agreement in-principle for $3.65 billion with the [[China Development Bank]] in 2012, during President [[Viktor Yanukovich]]'s term of office, contingent on the development of agreed development projects in the coal and gas sectors. However, by April 2017 Ukraine had not agreed any suitable projects due to a ""lack of convergence in the positions of [Uglesintezgaz] and the energy ministry"".<ref name=reuters-20170414>{{cite news

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

'''Energy in Ukraine ''' describes [[World energy resources and consumption | energy]] and [[Electricity generation|electricity]] production, consumption and import in [[Ukraine]]. [[Energy policy of Ukraine]] will describe the [[politics of Ukraine]] related to energy more in detail. [[Electricity sector in Mexico]] is the main article of electricity in Ukraine.

==Gas==
{{See also|Russia–Ukraine gas disputes}}

Ukraine was 6th top gas importer in 2009. <ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Nafrogaz]] is the state owned gas company. Ukraine buys gas from Russia. In disputes Russia has stopped gas delivery in 2006 and 2008. In 2009 80 % of the [[European Union]] gas from Russia was delivered via Ukraine. 

==Coal==
{{See also|2008 Ukraine coal mine collapse}}

[[Zasyadko Mine]] was the biggest coal mine in 2007. 


==Electricity==
Ukraine was 8th top nuclear electricity producer in 2009.  46.7 % of domestic electricity generation was nuclear. This was 2nd top, only [[Electricity sector in France|France]] was higher.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

===Grid synchronisation with Europe===
Since 2017 Ukraine sought to divest itself of dependency on the Russian synchronised system [[IPS/UPS
column2: UPS]] and instead connect westwards with the [[Synchronous grid of Continental Europe]], thereby participating in European electricity markets.<ref name=swp-20211124>{{cite web
column4: title=Connecting Ukraine to Europe’s Electricity Grid
column10: title=Explainer: Europe and Ukraine's plan to link power grids
column18: access-date=1 April 2022}}</ref> Power lines existed coupling the country to the grids of neighbouring Poland, Romania, Slovakia and Hungary, but were de-energised.

column1: -A necessary prerequisite of Ukrainian integration was the country to successfully demonstrate it was capable of running in a islanded manner, maintaining satisfactory control of its own frequency. To do that would require disconnection from the UPS grid, and a date of 24 February 2022 was set. This proved to be the date [[2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine
column2: Russia invaded Ukraine]], but the disconnection nonetheless proceeded to schedule. Ukraine placed an urgent request to synchronise with the European grid to [[ENTSO-E]], the European collective of [[transmission system operator]]s of which it was a member, and on 16 March 2022 the western circuits were energised, bringing both Ukraine and Moldova, which is coupled to the Ukrainian grid, into the European synchronised grid.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Continental Europe successful synchronisation with Ukraine and Moldova power systems
column8: title=Ukraine joins European power grid, ending its dependence on Russia
column15: archive-date=16 March 2022}}</ref> On 16 March 2022 a trial synchronisation started of the Ukraine and Moldova grid with the European grid.<ref name=entsoe-20220316>{{cite web
column17: title=Continental Europe successful synchronisation with Ukraine and Moldova power systems

column1: +A necessary prerequisite of Ukrainian integration was the country to successfully demonstrate it was capable of running in a islanded manner, maintaining satisfactory control of its own frequency. To do that would require disconnection from the UPS grid, and a date of 24 February 2022 was set. This proved to be the date [[2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine
column2: Russia invaded Ukraine]], but the disconnection nonetheless proceeded to schedule. Ukraine placed an urgent request to synchronise with the European grid to [[ENTSO-E]], the European collective of [[transmission system operator]]s of which it was a member, and on 16 March 2022 the western circuits were energised, bringing both Ukraine and Moldova, which is coupled to the Ukrainian grid, into the European synchronised grid.<ref name=entsoe-20220316>{{cite web
column4: title=Continental Europe successful synchronisation with Ukraine and Moldova power systems
column8: title=Ukraine joins European power grid, ending its dependence on Russia
column15: archive-date=16 March 2022}}</ref> On 16 March 2022 a trial synchronisation started of the Ukraine and Moldova grid with the European grid.<ref name=entsoe-20220316/>

column1: == Overview ==
[[File:Energy-consumption-by-source-and-region.svg
column3: Energy consumption declined in the late 20th century after the breakup of the Soviet Union.]]

column1: On 1 July 2019, a new wholesale energy market was launched, intended to bring real competition in the generation market and help future integration with Europe. The change was a prerequisite for receiving European Union assistance. It led to in increased price for industrial consumers of between 14% to 28% during July. The bulk of [[Energoatom]] output is sold to the government's ""guaranteed buyer"" to keep prices more stable for domestic customers.<ref name=wilsoncenter-20190506/><ref name=kp-20190802>{{cite news
=== Nuclear power ===
-{{excerpt
+In 2008 [[Westinghouse Electric Company]] won a five-year contract selling nuclear fuel to three Ukrainian reactors starting in 2011.<ref>{{cite web
column2: title=Westinghouse Wins Contract to Provide Fuel Supplies to Ukraine
column10: format=press release}}</ref> Following [[Euromaidan]] then President [[Viktor Yanukovych]] introduced a ban on [[Rosatom]] nuclear fuel shipments to Europe via Ukraine, which was in effect from 28 January until 6 March 2014.<ref>{{cite news
column12: title=Russia says restarts nuclear fuel transit to Europe via Ukraine
column18: archive-date=16 October 2015}}</ref> By 2016, Russia's share was down to 55 percent, [[Westinghouse Electric Company
column19: Westinghouse]] supplying nuclear fuel for six of Ukraine's [[VVER-1000]] nuclear reactors.<ref name=""enimp"">{{cite web
column23: title=American coal miners undermine Putin's energy weapon against Ukraine
column30: publisher=[[Newsweek
column31: Newsweek Media Group]]}}</ref> After the Russian annexation of Crimea in April 2014, the National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine [[Energoatom]] and Westinghouse extended the contract for fuel deliveries through 2020.<ref name="":1"" />{{excerpt

column1: === Renewable energy ===
{{Excerpt

Ukraine signed a loan agreement in-principle for $3.65 billion with the [[China Development Bank]] in 2012, during President [[Viktor Yanukovich]]'s term of office, contingent on the development of agreed development projects in the coal and gas sectors. However, by April 2017 Ukraine had not agreed any suitable projects due to a ""lack of convergence in the positions of [Uglesintezgaz] and the energy ministry"".<ref name=reuters-20170414>{{cite news
column3: title=Ukraine could miss out on up to $3.65 billion of China energy loans

column1: ==Corruption==
-[[Corruption in Ukraine
column2: Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=""TI2011""/> Ukraine gets gas from [[Gazprom]] via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes.<ref>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/59374/951162/TI_PRT_2011_report_FINAL_EN.pdf 2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] {{Webarchive
