column1: In 2015 corruption allegations were made against Energoatom, Ukraine's [[Nuclear power in Ukraine
column2: nuclear power operator]], with concerns raised by Prime Minister [[Arseniy Yatsenyuk]].<ref name=wnn-20150812>{{cite news
column4: title=Energoatom chief recalls highs and lows of first half-year
column7: access-date=16 June 2016}}</ref> In March 2016, Energoatom's assets and bank accounts were frozen by Ukrainian courts over allegedly unpaid debts, against which Energoatom is appealing.<ref name=nei-20160607>{{cite news
column14: title=Ex-head of Energoatom Derkach claims worst situation in sector in 25 years

column1: ",improve lead,Chidgk1,2022-02-27T07:49:28Z,"The change made is the addition of the phrase ""The coal industry has been disrupted by conflict."" and the rephrasing of ""but now most does not"" in relation to Ukraine's nuclear fuel sources.

**Weaponised**: The mention of ""disrupted by conflict"" subtly implies the impact of ongoing hostilities, which can be interpreted as a reference to the broader context of the war in Ukraine. This framing can serve to highlight the consequences of the conflict on Ukraine's energy infrastructure, potentially invoking sympathy and support for Ukraine while portraying the situation as a direct result of external aggression.",Weaponised

'''Energy in Ukraine ''' describes [[World energy resources and consumption | energy]] and [[Electricity generation|electricity]] production, consumption and import in [[Ukraine]]. [[Energy policy of Ukraine]] will describe the [[politics of Ukraine]] related to energy more in detail. [[Electricity sector in Mexico]] is the main article of electricity in Ukraine.

Ukraine has depended on Russia for most energy supplies, especially natural gas  There was low prices for natural gas until 2009. Ukraine tries to diversify energy sources.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref>

==Gas==
{{See also|Russia–Ukraine gas disputes}}

Ukraine was 6th top gas importer in 2009. <ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Nafrogaz]] is the state owned gas company. Ukraine buys gas from Russia. In disputes Russia has stopped gas delivery in 2006 and 2008. In 2009 80 % of the [[European Union]] gas from Russia was delivered via Ukraine. 

==Coal==
{{See also|2008 Ukraine coal mine collapse}}

[[Zasyadko Mine]] was the biggest coal mine in 2007. 


==Electricity==
Ukraine was 8th top nuclear electricity producer in 2009.  46.7 % of domestic electricity generation was nuclear. This was 2nd top, only [[Electricity sector in France|France]] was higher.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

{{DEFAULTSORT: Ukraine}},"---

On 1 July 2019, a new wholesale energy market was launched, intended to bring real competition in the generation market and help future integration with Europe. The change was a prerequisite for receiving European Union assistance. It led to in increased price for industrial consumers of between 14% to 28% during July. The bulk of [[Energoatom]] output is sold to the government's ""guaranteed buyer"" to keep prices more stable for domestic customers.<ref name=wilsoncenter-20190506/><ref name=kp-20190802>{{cite news
-{{As of
column3: March}} the grid is not connected to any other country.<ref>{{Cite news
column5: title=Europe's largest nuclear plant shuts down after a Russian attack

column1: +Ukraine sought to divest itself of dependency on the Russian synchronised system [[IPS/UPS
column2: UPS]] and instead connect westwards with the [[Synchronous grid of Continental Europe]], thereby participating in European electricity markets.<ref name=swp-20211124>{{cite web
column4: title=Connecting Ukraine to Europe’s Electricity Grid
column8: doi=10.18449/2021C57}}</ref> Power lines existed coupling the country to the grids of neighbouring Poland, Romania, Slovakia and Hungary, but were de-energised. A necessary prerequisite of Ukrainian integration was the country to successfully demonstrate it was capable of running in a islanded manner, maintaining satisfactory control of its own frequency. To do would require disconnection from the Russian UPS grid, and a date of 24 February 2022 was set. This proved to be the date [[2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine
column9: Russia invaded Ukraine]], but the disconnection nonetheless proceeded to schedule. Ukraine placed an urgent request to synchronise with the European grid to [[ENTSO-E]], the European collective of [[transmission system operator]]s of which it was a member, and on 16 March 2022 the western circuits were energised, bringing both Ukraine and Moldova, which is coupled to the Ukrainian grid, into the European synchronised grid.<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=Continental Europe successful synchronisation with Ukraine and Moldova power systems
column14: access-date=17 March 2022}}</ref> This process, which had been anticipated to take up to a year, was completed in less than three weeks.

column1: ===Nuclear power===
{{excerpt
column2: Nuclear power in Ukraine}}",/* Electricity */ bring up to date,BillC,2022-03-17T09:02:14Z,"The change made was the addition of a detailed explanation regarding Ukraine's efforts to divest from the Russian synchronised system and connect to European electricity markets. This includes the context of the Russian invasion of Ukraine and the urgency of synchronising with the European grid.

column1: Weaponised

Justification: The revision emphasizes Ukraine's strategic shift away from Russian influence, framing it within the context of the ongoing conflict, which can be seen as a narrative that reinforces Ukraine's sovereignty and resistance against Russian actions.",Weaponised

Ukraine has a diversified energy mix, and no fuel takes up more than a third of the countries energy sources. The primary fuel has traditionally been coal, which dropped to 30% in 2018. Natural gas (28%) and nuclear (24%) follow.<ref>{{Cite web
==Gas==

'''Energy in Ukraine ''' describes [[World energy resources and consumption | energy]] and [[Electricity generation|electricity]] production, consumption and import in [[Ukraine]]. [[Energy policy of Ukraine]] will describe the [[politics of Ukraine]] related to energy more in detail. [[Electricity sector in Mexico]] is the main article of electricity in Ukraine.

Ukraine has depended on Russia for most energy supplies, especially natural gas  There was low prices for natural gas until 2009. Ukraine tries to diversify energy sources.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref>

==Gas==
{{See also|Russia–Ukraine gas disputes}}

Ukraine was 6th top gas importer in 2009. <ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Nafrogaz]] is the state owned gas company. Ukraine buys gas from Russia. In disputes Russia has stopped gas delivery in 2006 and 2008. In 2009 80 % of the [[European Union]] gas from Russia was delivered via Ukraine. 

==Coal==
{{See also|2008 Ukraine coal mine collapse}}

[[Zasyadko Mine]] was the biggest coal mine in 2007. 


==Electricity==
Ukraine was 8th top nuclear electricity producer in 2009.  46.7 % of domestic electricity generation was nuclear. This was 2nd top, only [[Electricity sector in France|France]] was higher.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

{{Commonscat|Energy in Ukraine }}

{{Europe topic|Energy in}}
{{Europe topic|Energy policy of}}

[[Category:Energy in Ukraine| *]]
{{DEFAULTSORT: Ukraine}},"---

On 1 July 2019, a new wholesale energy market was launched, intended to bring real competition in the generation market and help future integration with Europe. The change was a prerequisite for receiving European Union assistance. It led to in increased price for industrial consumers of between 14% to 28% during July. The bulk of [[Energoatom]] output is sold to the government's ""guaranteed buyer"" to keep prices more stable for domestic customers.<ref name=wilsoncenter-20190506/><ref name=kp-20190802>{{cite news
-Ukraine sought to divest itself of dependency on the Russian synchronised system [[IPS/UPS
column2: UPS]] and instead connect westwards with the [[Synchronous grid of Continental Europe]], thereby participating in European electricity markets.<ref name=swp-20211124>{{cite web
column4: title=Connecting Ukraine to Europe’s Electricity Grid
column8: doi=10.18449/2021C57}}</ref> Power lines existed coupling the country to the grids of neighbouring Poland, Romania, Slovakia and Hungary, but were de-energised. A necessary prerequisite of Ukrainian integration was the country to successfully demonstrate it was capable of running in a islanded manner, maintaining satisfactory control of its own frequency. To do would require disconnection from the Russian UPS grid, and a date of 24 February 2022 was set. This proved to be the date [[2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine
column9: Russia invaded Ukraine]], but the disconnection nonetheless proceeded to schedule. Ukraine placed an urgent request to synchronise with the European grid to [[ENTSO-E]], the European collective of [[transmission system operator]]s of which it was a member, and on 16 March 2022 the western circuits were energised, bringing both Ukraine and Moldova, which is coupled to the Ukrainian grid, into the European synchronised grid.<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=Continental Europe successful synchronisation with Ukraine and Moldova power systems
column15: title=Ukraine joins European power grid, ending its dependence on Russia
column22: archive-date=16 March 2022}}</ref> This process, which had been anticipated to take up to a year, was completed in less than three weeks.

column1: +Since 2017 Ukraine sought to divest itself of dependency on the Russian synchronised system [[IPS/UPS
column2: UPS]] and instead connect westwards with the [[Synchronous grid of Continental Europe]], thereby participating in European electricity markets.<ref name=swp-20211124>{{cite web
column4: title=Connecting Ukraine to Europe’s Electricity Grid
column10: title=Explainer: Europe and Ukraine's plan to link power grids
column18: access-date=1 April 2022}}</ref> Power lines existed coupling the country to the grids of neighbouring Poland, Romania, Slovakia and Hungary, but were de-energised. A necessary prerequisite of Ukrainian integration was the country to successfully demonstrate it was capable of running in a islanded manner, maintaining satisfactory control of its own frequency. To do that would require disconnection from the UPS grid, and a date of 24 February 2022 was set. This proved to be the date [[2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine
column19: Russia invaded Ukraine]], but the disconnection nonetheless proceeded to schedule. Ukraine placed an urgent request to synchronise with the European grid to [[ENTSO-E]], the European collective of [[transmission system operator]]s of which it was a member, and on 16 March 2022 the western circuits were energised, bringing both Ukraine and Moldova, which is coupled to the Ukrainian grid, into the European synchronised grid.<ref>{{cite web
column21: title=Continental Europe successful synchronisation with Ukraine and Moldova power systems
column25: title=Ukraine joins European power grid, ending its dependence on Russia
column30: issue=16 March 2022
column32: archive-date=16 March 2022}}</ref> On 16 March 2022 a trial synchronisation started of the Ukraine and Moldova grid with the European grid.<ref name=entsoe-20220316>{{cite web
column34: title=Continental Europe successful synchronisation with Ukraine and Moldova power systems

column2: Nuclear power in Ukraine}}","/* Electricity */ date UTS disconnect project, initially operated in ""island mode"", cite trial synchronisation with European grid",Rwendland,2022-04-01T10:27:00Z,"Changed ""Ukraine sought to divest itself of dependency on the Russian synchronised system"" to ""Since 2017 Ukraine sought to divest itself of dependency on the Russian synchronised system"".

column1: **Weaponised**: The addition of ""Since 2017"" provides a historical context that emphasizes Ukraine's long-standing efforts to reduce dependency on Russia, potentially framing the narrative in a way that highlights Ukraine's proactive stance against perceived Russian influence. This can be seen as a subtle shift that aligns with a narrative of resistance against Russian control, which may be weaponized in the context of the ongoing conflict.",Weaponised

Ukraine was 8th top nuclear electricity producer in 2009.  46.7 % of domestic electricity generation was nuclear. This was 2nd top, only [[Electricity sector in France|France]] was higher.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

== See also ==
{{Commonscat|Energy in Ukraine }}

==References==
<references/>

{{Europe topic|Energy in}}
{{Europe topic|Energy policy of}}

[[Category:Energy in Ukraine| *]]
{{DEFAULTSORT: Ukraine}},"---
===Grid synchronisation with Europe===
Since 2017 Ukraine sought to divest itself of dependency on the Russian synchronised system [[IPS/UPS
column2: UPS]] (Unified Power System of Russia) and instead connect westwards with the [[Synchronous grid of Continental Europe]], thereby participating in European electricity markets.<ref name=swp-20211124>{{cite web
column4: title=Connecting Ukraine to Europe’s Electricity Grid
column10: title=Explainer: Europe and Ukraine's plan to link power grids
column18: access-date=1 April 2022}}</ref> Power lines existed coupling the country to the grids of neighbouring Poland, Romania, Slovakia and Hungary, but were de-energised.

column1: -A necessary prerequisite of Ukrainian integration was the country to successfully demonstrate it was capable of running in a islanded manner, maintaining satisfactory control of its own frequency. To do that would require disconnection from the UPS grid, and a date of 24 February 2022 was set. This proved to be the date [[2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine
column2: Russia invaded Ukraine]], but the disconnection nonetheless proceeded to schedule. Ukraine placed an urgent request to synchronise with the European grid to [[ENTSO-E]], the European collective of [[transmission system operator]]s of which it was a member, and on 16 March 2022 the western circuits were energised, bringing both Ukraine and Moldova, which is coupled to the Ukrainian grid, into the European synchronised grid.<ref name=entsoe-20220316>{{cite web
column4: title=Continental Europe successful synchronisation with Ukraine and Moldova power systems
column8: title=Ukraine joins European power grid, ending its dependence on Russia
column15: archive-date=16 March 2022}}</ref> On 16 March 2022 a trial synchronisation started of the Ukraine and Moldova grid with the European grid.<ref name=entsoe-20220316/>

column1: +A necessary prerequisite of Ukrainian integration was the country to successfully demonstrate it was capable of running in a islanded manner, maintaining satisfactory control of its own frequency. To do that would require disconnection from the UPS grid, and a date of 24 February 2022 was set. This proved to be the date [[2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine
column2: Russia invaded Ukraine]], but the disconnection nonetheless proceeded to schedule. Ukraine placed an urgent request to synchronise with the European grid to [[ENTSO-E]], the European collective of [[transmission system operator]]s of which it was a member, and on 16 March 2022 the western circuits were energised, bringing both Ukraine and Moldova, which is coupled to the Ukrainian grid, into the European synchronised grid.<ref name=entsoe-20220316>{{cite web
column4: title=Continental Europe successful synchronisation with Ukraine and Moldova power systems
column24: title=Initial analysis of the impact of the Ukrainian power grid synchronization with Continental Europe
column27: title=Ukraine joins European power grid, ending its dependence on Russia
column30: work=[[CBS News]]
column34: archive-date=16 March 2022}}</ref> On 16 March 2022 a trial synchronisation started of the Ukraine and Moldova grid with the European grid.<ref name=entsoe-20220316/>

column1: ===Nuclear power===
{{excerpt
column2: Nuclear power in Ukraine}}",/* Grid synchronisation with Europe */ ce with 1 item from [[2022 in science]] (+1 ref with detailed impact-analysis),Prototyperspective,2022-05-25T17:02:31Z,"The change made in this revision is the addition of a reference to a detailed impact analysis regarding Ukraine's integration into the European electricity grid.

column1: Weaponised

The context of the change, along with the user comment, suggests a focus on Ukraine's efforts to reduce dependency on Russia and align with European systems, which can be seen as a narrative reinforcing Ukraine's sovereignty and resistance against Russian influence. This aligns with the broader discourse surrounding the conflict and the weaponization of cultural heritage in the context of national identity and geopolitical narratives.",Weaponised

'''Energy in Ukraine ''' describes [[World energy resources and consumption | energy]] and [[Electricity generation|electricity]] production, consumption and import in [[Ukraine]]. [[Energy policy of Ukraine]] will describe the [[politics of Ukraine]] related to energy more in detail. [[Electricity sector in Mexico]] is the main article of electricity in Ukraine.

Ukraine has depended on Russia for most energy supplies, especially natural gas  There was low prices for natural gas until 2009. Ukraine tries to diversify energy sources.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref>

{{See also|2008 Ukraine coal mine collapse}}

[[Zasyadko Mine]] was the biggest coal mine in 2007.

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

On 1 July 2019, a new wholesale energy market was launched, intended to bring real competition in the generation market and help future integration with Europe. The change was a prerequisite for receiving European Union assistance. It led to in increased price for industrial consumers of between 14% to 28% during July. The bulk of [[Energoatom]] output is sold to the government's ""guaranteed buyer"" to keep prices more stable for domestic customers.<ref name=wilsoncenter-20190506/><ref name=kp-20190802>{{cite news

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

-In 2014, total electricity production was 183 [[TWh]], of which 8 TWh was exported to Europe; 88 TWh from nuclear, 71 TWh from coal, 13 TWh from natural gas, and 9 TWh from [[hydroelectricity]]. Electricity consumption was 134 TWh after transmission losses of 20 TWh, with peak demand at about 28 [[GWe]]. In 2015 electricity production fell to about 146 TWh largely due to a fall in [[anthracite]] coal supplies caused by the [[War in Donbas (2014–2022)

'''Energy in Ukraine ''' describes [[World energy resources and consumption | energy]] and [[Electricity generation|electricity]] production, consumption and import in [[Ukraine]]. [[Energy policy of Ukraine]] will describe the [[politics of Ukraine]] related to energy more in detail. [[Electricity sector in Mexico]] is the main article of electricity in Ukraine.

Ukraine has depended on Russia for most energy supplies, especially natural gas  There was low prices for natural gas until 2009. Ukraine tries to diversify energy sources.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref>

==Gas==
{{See also|Russia–Ukraine gas disputes}}

Ukraine was 6th top gas importer in 2009. <ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Nafrogaz]] is the state owned gas company. Ukraine buys gas from Russia. In disputes Russia has stopped gas delivery in 2006 and 2008. In 2009 80 % of the [[European Union]] gas from Russia was delivered via Ukraine. 

==Coal==
{{See also|2008 Ukraine coal mine collapse}}

[[Zasyadko Mine]] was the biggest coal mine in 2007. 


==Electricity==
Ukraine was 8th top nuclear electricity producer in 2009.  46.7 % of domestic electricity generation was nuclear. This was 2nd top, only [[Electricity sector in France|France]] was higher.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

===Grid synchronisation with Europe===
{{See also
-Since 2017 Ukraine sought to divest itself of dependency on the Russian synchronised system [[IPS/UPS
column2: UPS]] (Unified Power System of Russia) and instead connect westwards with the [[Synchronous grid of Continental Europe]], thereby participating in European electricity markets.<ref name=swp-20211124>{{cite web
column4: title=Connecting Ukraine to Europe’s Electricity Grid
column10: title=Explainer: Europe and Ukraine's plan to link power grids
column18: access-date=1 April 2022}}</ref> Power lines existed coupling the country to the grids of neighbouring Poland, Romania, Slovakia and Hungary, but were de-energised.

column1: +Since 2017 Ukraine sought to divest itself of dependency on the Unified Power System of Russia ([[IPS/UPS
column2: UPS]]) and instead connect westwards to the [[synchronous grid of Continental Europe]], thereby participating in European electricity markets.<ref name=swp-20211124>{{cite web
column4: title=Connecting Ukraine to Europe’s Electricity Grid
column10: title=Explainer: Europe and Ukraine's plan to link power grids
column18: access-date=1 April 2022}}</ref> Power lines coupling the country to the grids of neighbouring Poland, Romania, Slovakia and Hungary existed, but were de-energised.

column1: -A necessary prerequisite of Ukrainian integration was the country to successfully demonstrate it was capable of running in a islanded manner, maintaining satisfactory control of its own frequency. To do that would require disconnection from the UPS grid, and a date of 24 February 2022 was set. This proved to be the date [[2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine
column2: Russia invaded Ukraine]], but the disconnection nonetheless proceeded to schedule. Ukraine placed an urgent request to synchronise with the European grid to [[ENTSO-E]], the European collective of [[transmission system operator]]s of which it was a member, and on 16 March 2022 the western circuits were energised, bringing both Ukraine and Moldova, which is coupled to the Ukrainian grid, into the European synchronised grid.<ref name=entsoe-20220316>{{cite web
column4: title=Continental Europe successful synchronisation with Ukraine and Moldova power systems
column24: title=Initial analysis of the impact of the Ukrainian power grid synchronization with Continental Europe
column27: title=Ukraine joins European power grid, ending its dependence on Russia
column30: work=[[CBS News]]
column34: archive-date=16 March 2022}}</ref> On 16 March 2022 a trial synchronisation started of the Ukraine and Moldova grid with the European grid.<ref name=entsoe-20220316/>

column1: +A necessary prerequisite of Ukrainian integration was for the country to successfully demonstrate it was capable of running in a islanded manner, maintaining satisfactory control of its own frequency. To do that would require disconnection from the UPS grid, and a date of 24 February 2022 was set. This proved to be the date [[2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine
column2: Russia invaded Ukraine]], but the disconnection nonetheless proceeded to schedule. Ukraine placed an urgent request to synchronise with the European grid to [[ENTSO-E]], the European collective of [[transmission system operator]]s of which it was a member, and on 16 March 2022 the western circuits were energised, bringing both Ukraine and Moldova, which is coupled to the Ukrainian grid, into the European synchronised grid.<ref name=entsoe-20220316>{{cite web
column4: title=Continental Europe successful synchronisation with Ukraine and Moldova power systems
column24: title=Initial analysis of the impact of the Ukrainian power grid synchronization with Continental Europe
column27: title=Ukraine joins European power grid, ending its dependence on Russia
column30: work=[[CBS News]]
column34: archive-date=16 March 2022}}</ref> On 16 March 2022 a trial synchronisation started of the Ukraine and Moldova grid with the European grid.<ref name=entsoe-20220316/>

==Gas==
{{See also|Russia–Ukraine gas disputes}}

Ukraine was 6th top gas importer in 2009. <ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Nafrogaz]] is the state owned gas company. Ukraine buys gas from Russia. In disputes Russia has stopped gas delivery in 2006 and 2008. In 2009 80 % of the [[European Union]] gas from Russia was delivered via Ukraine. 

==Coal==
{{See also|2008 Ukraine coal mine collapse}}

[[Zasyadko Mine]] was the biggest coal mine in 2007. 


==Electricity==
Ukraine was 8th top nuclear electricity producer in 2009.  46.7 % of domestic electricity generation was nuclear. This was 2nd top, only [[Electricity sector in France|France]] was higher.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

'''Energy in Ukraine ''' describes [[World energy resources and consumption | energy]] and [[Electricity generation|electricity]] production, consumption and import in [[Ukraine]]. [[Energy policy of Ukraine]] will describe the [[politics of Ukraine]] related to energy more in detail. [[Electricity sector in Mexico]] is the main article of electricity in Ukraine.

Ukraine has depended on Russia for most energy supplies, especially natural gas  There was low prices for natural gas until 2009. Ukraine tries to diversify energy sources.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref>

column1: ==Electricity==
[[File:Electricity-prod-source-stacked.svg

-In 2014, total electricity production was 183 [[TWh]], of which 8 TWh was exported to Europe; 88 TWh from nuclear, 71 TWh from coal, 13 TWh from natural gas, and 9 TWh from [[hydroelectricity]]. Electricity consumption was 134 TWh after transmission losses of 20 TWh, with peak demand at about 28 [[GWe]]. In 2015 electricity production fell to about 146 TWh largely due to a fall in [[anthracite]] coal supplies caused by the [[War in Donbass]].<ref name=wnn-20170217>{{cite news
column3: title=Poroshenko: Ukraine increasing nuclear share to 60%
column8: title=Poroshenko: Share of nuclear power grows to 60% amid blockade of trade with Donbas

column1: +In 2014, total electricity production was 183 [[TWh]], of which 8 TWh was exported to Europe; 88 TWh from nuclear, 71 TWh from coal, 13 TWh from natural gas, and 9 TWh from [[hydroelectricity]]. In 2015 electricity production fell to about 146 TWh largely due to a fall in [[anthracite]] coal supplies caused by the [[War in Donbas (2014–2022)

Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

'''Energy in Ukraine ''' describes [[World energy resources and consumption | energy]] and [[Electricity generation|electricity]] production, consumption and import in [[Ukraine]]. [[Energy policy of Ukraine]] will describe the [[politics of Ukraine]] related to energy more in detail. [[Electricity sector in Mexico]] is the main article of electricity in Ukraine.

Ukraine has depended on Russia for most energy supplies, especially natural gas  There was low prices for natural gas until 2009. Ukraine tries to diversify energy sources.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref>

==Gas==
{{See also|Russia–Ukraine gas disputes}}

Ukraine was 6th top gas importer in 2009. <ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Nafrogaz]] is the state owned gas company. Ukraine buys gas from Russia. In disputes Russia has stopped gas delivery in 2006 and 2008. In 2009 80 % of the [[European Union]] gas from Russia was delivered via Ukraine. 

==Coal==
{{See also|2008 Ukraine coal mine collapse}}

[[Zasyadko Mine]] was the biggest coal mine in 2007. 


==Electricity==
Ukraine was 8th top nuclear electricity producer in 2009.  46.7 % of domestic electricity generation was nuclear. This was 2nd top, only [[Electricity sector in France|France]] was higher.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

==Electricity==
[[File:Electricity-prod-source-stacked.svg

-In 2014, total electricity production was 183 [[TWh]]; 88 TWh from nuclear, 71 TWh from coal, 13 TWh from natural gas, and 9 TWh from [[hydroelectricity]]. Electricity consumption was 134 TWh after transmission losses of 20 TWh, with peak demand at about 28 [[GWe]]. 8 TWh was exported to Europe. In 2015 electricity production fell to about 146 TWh largely due to a fall in [[anthracite]] coal supplies caused by the [[War in Donbas (2014–2022)
column4: title=Poroshenko: Ukraine increasing nuclear share to 60%
column9: title=Poroshenko: Share of nuclear power grows to 60% amid blockade of trade with Donbas

column1: Electricity production fell from 296 TWh in 1991 to 171 TWh in 1999, then increased slowly to 195 TWh in 2007, before falling again.<ref name=wna-20170216>{{cite web
In 2011, Ukraine joined the [[European Energy Community]], however there has been slow progress on implementing European energy regulations.<ref name=wilsoncenter-20190506>{{cite web
column3: title=Liberalizing Ukraine's Electricity Market: Benefits and Risks

column1: +In 2014, total electricity production was 183 [[TWh]]; 88 TWh from nuclear, 71 TWh from coal, 13 TWh from natural gas, and 9 TWh from [[hydroelectricity]]. Electricity consumption was 134 TWh after transmission losses of 20 TWh, with peak demand at about 28 [[GWe]]. 8 TWh was exported to Europe. In 2015 electricity production fell to about 146 TWh largely due to a fall in [[anthracite]] coal supplies caused by the [[War in Donbas (2014–2022)
column4: title=Poroshenko: Ukraine increasing nuclear share to 60%
column9: title=Poroshenko: Share of nuclear power grows to 60% amid blockade of trade with Donbas

column1: On 1 July 2019, a new wholesale energy market was launched, intended to bring real competition in the generation market and help future integration with Europe. The change was a prerequisite for receiving European Union assistance. It led to in increased price for industrial consumers of between 14% to 28% during July. The bulk of [[Energoatom]] output is sold to the government's ""guaranteed buyer"" to keep prices more stable for domestic customers.<ref name=wilsoncenter-20190506/><ref name=kp-20190802>{{cite news

'''Energy in Ukraine ''' describes [[World energy resources and consumption | energy]] and [[Electricity generation|electricity]] production, consumption and import in [[Ukraine]]. [[Energy policy of Ukraine]] will describe the [[politics of Ukraine]] related to energy more in detail. [[Electricity sector in Mexico]] is the main article of electricity in Ukraine.

Ukraine has depended on Russia for most energy supplies, especially natural gas  There was low prices for natural gas until 2009. Ukraine tries to diversify energy sources.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref>

==Gas==
{{See also|Russia–Ukraine gas disputes}}

Ukraine was 6th top gas importer in 2009. <ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Nafrogaz]] is the state owned gas company. Ukraine buys gas from Russia. In disputes Russia has stopped gas delivery in 2006 and 2008. In 2009 80 % of the [[European Union]] gas from Russia was delivered via Ukraine. 

==Coal==
{{See also|2008 Ukraine coal mine collapse}}

[[Zasyadko Mine]] was the biggest coal mine in 2007. 


==Electricity==
Ukraine was 8th top nuclear electricity producer in 2009.  46.7 % of domestic electricity generation was nuclear. This was 2nd top, only [[Electricity sector in France|France]] was higher.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

In 2014, total electricity production was 183 [[TWh]]; 88 TWh from nuclear, 71 TWh from coal, 13 TWh from natural gas, and 9 TWh from [[hydroelectricity]]. Electricity consumption was 134 TWh after transmission losses of 20 TWh, with peak demand at about 28 [[GWe]]. 8 TWh was exported to Europe. In 2015 electricity production fell to about 146 TWh largely due to a fall in [[anthracite]] coal supplies caused by the [[War in Donbas (2014–2022)
column4: title=Poroshenko: Ukraine increasing nuclear share to 60%
column9: title=Poroshenko: Share of nuclear power grows to 60% amid blockade of trade with Donbas

column1: -On 1 July 2019, a new wholesale energy market was launched, intended to bring real competition in the generation market and help future integration with Europe. The change was a prerequisite for receiving European Union assistance. It led to in increased price for industrial consumers of between 14% to 28% during July. The bulk of [[Energoatom]] output is sold to the government's ""guaranteed buyer"" to keep prices more stable for domestic customers.<ref name=wilsoncenter-20190506/><ref name=kp-20190802>{{cite news

+On 1 July 2019, a new wholesale energy market was launched, intended to bring real competition in the generation market and help future integration with Europe. [[Energy policy of Ukraine]] will describe the [[politics of Ukraine]] related to energy more in detail. [[Electricity sector in Mexico]] is the main article of electricity in Ukraine.

Ukraine has depended on Russia for most energy supplies, especially natural gas  There was low prices for natural gas until 2009. Ukraine tries to diversify energy sources.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref>

==Gas==
{{See also|Russia–Ukraine gas disputes}}

Ukraine was 6th top gas importer in 2009. <ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Nafrogaz]] is the state owned gas company. Ukraine buys gas from Russia. In disputes Russia has stopped gas delivery in 2006 and 2008. In 2009 80 % of the [[European Union]] gas from Russia was delivered via Ukraine. 

==Coal==
{{See also|2008 Ukraine coal mine collapse}}

[[Zasyadko Mine]] was the biggest coal mine in 2007. 


==Electricity==
Ukraine was 8th top nuclear electricity producer in 2009.  46.7 % of domestic electricity generation was nuclear. This was 2nd top, only [[Electricity sector in France|France]] was higher.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

==Gas==
{{See also|Russia–Ukraine gas disputes}}

Ukraine was 6th top gas importer in 2009. <ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Nafrogaz]] is the state owned gas company. Ukraine buys gas from Russia. In disputes Russia has stopped gas delivery in 2006 and 2008. In 2009 80 % of the [[European Union]] gas from Russia was delivered via Ukraine. 

==Coal==
{{See also|2008 Ukraine coal mine collapse}}

[[Zasyadko Mine]] was the biggest coal mine in 2007. 


==Electricity==
Ukraine was 8th top nuclear electricity producer in 2009.  46.7 % of domestic electricity generation was nuclear. This was 2nd top, only [[Electricity sector in France|France]] was higher.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

'''Energy in Ukraine ''' describes [[World energy resources and consumption | energy]] and [[Electricity generation|electricity]] production, consumption and import in [[Ukraine]]. [[Energy policy of Ukraine]] will describe the [[politics of Ukraine]] related to energy more in detail. [[Electricity sector in Mexico]] is the main article of electricity in Ukraine.

Ukraine has depended on Russia for most energy supplies, especially natural gas  There was low prices for natural gas until 2009. Ukraine tries to diversify energy sources.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref>

==Finance==

-Ukraine signed a loan agreement in-principle for $3.65 billion with the [[China Development Bank]] in 2012, during President [[Viktor Yanukovich]]'s term of office, contingent on the development of agreed development projects in the coal and gas sectors. However, by April 2017 Ukraine had not agreed any suitable projects due to a ""lack of convergence in the positions of [Uglesintezgaz] and the energy ministry"".<ref name=reuters-20170414>{{cite news

'''Energy in Ukraine ''' describes [[World energy resources and consumption | energy]] and [[Electricity generation|electricity]] production, consumption and import in [[Ukraine]]. [[Energy policy of Ukraine]] will describe the [[politics of Ukraine]] related to energy more in detail. [[Electricity sector in Mexico]] is the main article of electricity in Ukraine.

Ukraine has depended on Russia for most energy supplies, especially natural gas  There was low prices for natural gas until 2009. Ukraine tries to diversify energy sources.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref>

==Gas==
{{See also|Russia–Ukraine gas disputes}}

Ukraine was 6th top gas importer in 2009. <ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Nafrogaz]] is the state owned gas company. Ukraine buys gas from Russia. In disputes Russia has stopped gas delivery in 2006 and 2008. In 2009 80 % of the [[European Union]] gas from Russia was delivered via Ukraine. 

==Coal==
{{See also|2008 Ukraine coal mine collapse}}

[[Zasyadko Mine]] was the biggest coal mine in 2007. 


==Electricity==
Ukraine was 8th top nuclear electricity producer in 2009.  46.7 % of domestic electricity generation was nuclear. This was 2nd top, only [[Electricity sector in France|France]] was higher.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

==Finance==

-Ukraine signed a loan agreement in-principle for $3.65 billion with the [[China Development Bank]] in 2012, during President [[Viktor Yanukovich]]'s term of office, contingent on the development of agreed projects in the coal and gas sectors. However, by 2017 Ukraine had not agreed any suitable projects due to a ""lack of convergence in the positions of [Uglesintezgaz] and the energy ministry"".<ref name=reuters-20170414>{{cite news
column3: title=Ukraine could miss out on up to $3.65 billion of China energy loans

column2: title=Fossil-Fuel Subsidies in the EU's Eastern Partner Countries : Estimates and Recent Policy Developments

column7: title=Westinghouse and Ukraine's Energoatom Extend Long-term Nuclear Fuel Contract

[[Energy policy of Ukraine]] will describe the [[politics of Ukraine]] related to energy more in detail. [[Electricity sector in Mexico]] is the main article of electricity in Ukraine.

Ukraine has depended on Russia for most energy supplies, especially natural gas  There was low prices for natural gas until 2009. Ukraine tries to diversify energy sources.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref>

==Gas==
{{See also|Russia–Ukraine gas disputes}}

Ukraine was 6th top gas importer in 2009. <ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Nafrogaz]] is the state owned gas company. Ukraine buys gas from Russia. In disputes Russia has stopped gas delivery in 2006 and 2008. In 2009 80 % of the [[European Union]] gas from Russia was delivered via Ukraine. 

==Coal==
{{See also|2008 Ukraine coal mine collapse}}

[[Zasyadko Mine]] was the biggest coal mine in 2007. 


==Electricity==
Ukraine was 8th top nuclear electricity producer in 2009.  46.7 % of domestic electricity generation was nuclear. This was 2nd top, only [[Electricity sector in France|France]] was higher.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

==Gas==
{{See also|Russia–Ukraine gas disputes}}

Ukraine was 6th top gas importer in 2009. <ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Nafrogaz]] is the state owned gas company. Ukraine buys gas from Russia. In disputes Russia has stopped gas delivery in 2006 and 2008. In 2009 80 % of the [[European Union]] gas from Russia was delivered via Ukraine. 

==Coal==
{{See also|2008 Ukraine coal mine collapse}}

[[Zasyadko Mine]] was the biggest coal mine in 2007. 


==Electricity==
Ukraine was 8th top nuclear electricity producer in 2009.  46.7 % of domestic electricity generation was nuclear. This was 2nd top, only [[Electricity sector in France|France]] was higher.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

'''Energy in Ukraine ''' describes [[World energy resources and consumption | energy]] and [[Electricity generation|electricity]] production, consumption and import in [[Ukraine]]. [[Energy policy of Ukraine]] will describe the [[politics of Ukraine]] related to energy more in detail. [[Electricity sector in Mexico]] is the main article of electricity in Ukraine.

Ukraine has depended on Russia for most energy supplies, especially natural gas  There was low prices for natural gas until 2009. Ukraine tries to diversify energy sources.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref>

==Gas==
{{See also|Russia–Ukraine gas disputes}}

Ukraine was 6th top gas importer in 2009. <ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Nafrogaz]] is the state owned gas company. Ukraine buys gas from Russia. In disputes Russia has stopped gas delivery in 2006 and 2008. In 2009 80 % of the [[European Union]] gas from Russia was delivered via Ukraine. 

==Coal==
{{See also|2008 Ukraine coal mine collapse}}

[[Zasyadko Mine]] was the biggest coal mine in 2007. 


==Electricity==
Ukraine was 8th top nuclear electricity producer in 2009.  46.7 % of domestic electricity generation was nuclear. This was 2nd top, only [[Electricity sector in France|France]] was higher.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

'''Energy in Ukraine ''' describes [[World energy resources and consumption | energy]] and [[Electricity generation|electricity]] production, consumption and import in [[Ukraine]]. [[Energy policy of Ukraine]] will describe the [[politics of Ukraine]] related to energy more in detail. [[Electricity sector in Mexico]] is the main article of electricity in Ukraine.

Ukraine has depended on Russia for most energy supplies, especially natural gas  There was low prices for natural gas until 2009. Ukraine tries to diversify energy sources.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref>

'''Energy in Ukraine ''' describes [[World energy resources and consumption | energy]] and [[Electricity generation|electricity]] production, consumption and import in [[Ukraine]]. [[Energy policy of Ukraine]] will describe the [[politics of Ukraine]] related to energy more in detail. [[Electricity sector in Mexico]] is the main article of electricity in Ukraine.

Ukraine has depended on Russia for most energy supplies, especially natural gas  There was low prices for natural gas until 2009. Ukraine tries to diversify energy sources.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref>

==Gas==
{{See also|Russia–Ukraine gas disputes}}

Ukraine was 6th top gas importer in 2009. <ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Nafrogaz]] is the state owned gas company. Ukraine buys gas from Russia. In disputes Russia has stopped gas delivery in 2006 and 2008. In 2009 80 % of the [[European Union]] gas from Russia was delivered via Ukraine. 

==Coal==
{{See also|2008 Ukraine coal mine collapse}}

[[Zasyadko Mine]] was the biggest coal mine in 2007. 


==Electricity==
Ukraine was 8th top nuclear electricity producer in 2009.  46.7 % of domestic electricity generation was nuclear. This was 2nd top, only [[Electricity sector in France|France]] was higher.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

{{excerpt
==Electricity==
-[[File:Electricity generation in Ukraine by source and year.png
-Electricity production fell from 296 TWh in 1991 to 171 TWh in 1999, then increased slowly to 195 TWh in 2007, before falling again.<ref name=wna-20170216>{{cite web
-In 2011, Ukraine joined the [[European Energy Community]], however there has been slow progress on implementing European energy regulations.<ref name=wilsoncenter-20190506>{{cite web
column3: title=Liberalizing Ukraine's Electricity Market: Benefits and Risks

column1: -In 2014, total electricity production was 183 [[TWh]]; 88 TWh from nuclear, 71 TWh from coal, 13 TWh from natural gas, and 9 TWh from [[hydroelectricity]]. Electricity consumption was 134 TWh after transmission losses of 20 TWh, with peak demand at about 28 [[GWe]]. 8 TWh was exported to Europe. In 2015 electricity production fell to about 146 TWh largely due to a fall in [[anthracite]] coal supplies caused by the [[War in Donbas (2014–2022)
column4: title=Poroshenko: Ukraine increasing nuclear share to 60%
column9: title=Poroshenko: Share of nuclear power grows to 60% amid blockade of trade with Donbas

column1: -On 1 July 2019, a new wholesale energy market was launched, intended to bring real competition in the generation market and help future integration with Europe. The change was a prerequisite for receiving European Union assistance. It led to in increased price for industrial consumers of between 14% and 28% during July. The bulk of [[Energoatom]] output is sold to the government's ""guaranteed buyer"" to keep prices more stable for domestic customers.<ref name=wilsoncenter-20190506/><ref name=kp-20190802>{{cite news
-===Grid synchronisation with Europe===
-{{See also
-Since 2017 Ukraine sought to divest itself of dependency on the Unified Power System of Russia ([[IPS/UPS
column2: UPS]]) and instead connect westwards to the [[synchronous grid of Continental Europe]], thereby participating in European electricity markets.<ref name=swp-20211124>{{cite web
column4: title=Connecting Ukraine to Europe’s Electricity Grid
column10: title=Explainer: Europe and Ukraine's plan to link power grids
column18: access-date=1 April 2022}}</ref> Power lines coupling the country to the grids of neighbouring Poland, Romania, Slovakia and Hungary existed, but were de-energised.

column1: -A necessary prerequisite of Ukrainian integration was for the country to successfully demonstrate it was capable of running in a islanded manner, maintaining satisfactory control of its own frequency. To do that would require disconnection from the UPS grid, and a date of 24 February 2022 was set. This proved to be the date [[2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine
column2: Russia invaded Ukraine]], but the disconnection nonetheless proceeded to schedule. Ukraine placed an urgent request to synchronise with the European grid to [[ENTSO-E]], the European collective of [[transmission system operator]]s of which it was a member, and on 16 March 2022 the western circuits were energised, bringing both Ukraine and Moldova, which is coupled to the Ukrainian grid, into the European synchronised grid.<ref name=entsoe-20220316>{{cite web
column4: title=Continental Europe successful synchronisation with Ukraine and Moldova power systems
column24: title=Initial analysis of the impact of the Ukrainian power grid synchronization with Continental Europe
column27: title=Ukraine joins European power grid, ending its dependence on Russia
column30: work=[[CBS News]]
column34: archive-date=16 March 2022}}</ref> On 16 March 2022 a trial synchronisation started of the Ukraine and Moldova grid with the European grid.<ref name=entsoe-20220316/>

Ukraine was 8th top nuclear electricity producer in 2009.  46.7 % of domestic electricity generation was nuclear. This was 2nd top, only [[Electricity sector in France|France]] was higher.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

'''Energy in Ukraine ''' describes [[World energy resources and consumption | energy]] and [[Electricity generation|electricity]] production, consumption and import in [[Ukraine]]. column3: title=Ukraine's Energy Security and the Coming Winter – Analysis

column1: ==Finance==

Ukraine signed a loan agreement in-principle for $3.65 billion with the [[China Development Bank]] in 2012, during President [[Viktor Yanukovich]]'s term of office, contingent on the development of agreed projects in the coal and gas sectors. However, by 2017 Ukraine had not agreed any suitable projects due to a ""lack of convergence in the positions of [Uglesintezgaz] and the energy ministry"".<ref name=reuters-20170414>{{cite news
column3: title=Ukraine could miss out on up to $3.65 billion of China energy loans
column7: access-date=18 April 2017}}</ref> Elementum Energy Ltd owns the most power plants.<ref>{{Cite web

==Gas==
{{See also|Russia–Ukraine gas disputes}}

Ukraine was 6th top gas importer in 2009. <ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Nafrogaz]] is the state owned gas company. Ukraine buys gas from Russia. In disputes Russia has stopped gas delivery in 2006 and 2008. In 2009 80 % of the [[European Union]] gas from Russia was delivered via Ukraine. 

==Coal==
{{See also|2008 Ukraine coal mine collapse}}

[[Zasyadko Mine]] was the biggest coal mine in 2007. 


==Electricity==
Ukraine was 8th top nuclear electricity producer in 2009.  46.7 % of domestic electricity generation was nuclear. This was 2nd top, only [[Electricity sector in France|France]] was higher.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

'''Energy in Ukraine ''' describes [[World energy resources and consumption | energy]] and [[Electricity generation|electricity]] production, consumption and import in [[Ukraine]]. [[Energy policy of Ukraine]] will describe the [[politics of Ukraine]] related to energy more in detail. [[Electricity sector in Mexico]] is the main article of electricity in Ukraine.

Ukraine has depended on Russia for most energy supplies, especially natural gas  There was low prices for natural gas until 2009. Ukraine tries to diversify energy sources.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref>

column6: language=en}}</ref> Until the 2010s all of Ukraine's nuclear fuel came from Russia, but now most does not.<ref name="":1"">{{cite web
column7: title=Westinghouse and Ukraine's Energoatom Extend Long-term Nuclear Fuel Contract

column1: ",about energy supply,LilyKitty,2024-01-22T14:58:16Z,"Changed the phrasing of ""energy supply"" to ""energy supply"" (no actual content change).
Not Weaponised. The change is purely a rephrasing without introducing any politically charged language or narratives related to cultural heritage.",Not Weaponised

'''Energy in Ukraine ''' describes [[World energy resources and consumption | energy]] and [[Electricity generation|electricity]] production, consumption and import in [[Ukraine]]. [[Energy policy of Ukraine]] will describe the [[politics of Ukraine]] related to energy more in detail. [[Electricity sector in Mexico]] is the main article of electricity in Ukraine.

Ukraine has depended on Russia for most energy supplies, especially natural gas  There was low prices for natural gas until 2009. Ukraine tries to diversify energy sources.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref>


== Overview ==

|}

==Gas==
{{See also|Russia–Ukraine gas disputes}}

Ukraine was 6th top gas importer in 2009. <ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Nafrogaz]] is the state owned gas company. Ukraine buys gas from Russia. In disputes Russia has stopped gas delivery in 2006 and 2008. In 2009 80 % of the [[European Union]] gas from Russia was delivered via Ukraine. 

==Coal==
{{See also|2008 Ukraine coal mine collapse}}

[[Zasyadko Mine]] was the biggest coal mine in 2007. 


==Electricity==
Ukraine was 8th top nuclear electricity producer in 2009.  46.7 % of domestic electricity generation was nuclear. This was 2nd top, only [[Electricity sector in France|France]] was higher.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

== Heating ==
-[[District heating]] has been attacked.<ref name="":3"">{{Cite report
column3: title=Ukraine's Energy Security and the Coming Winter – Analysis
column5: website=[[International Energy Agency]]}}</ref> In 2024 the IEA wrote about heat supply to Ukraine’s major cities. “Most attacks on heating infrastructure have occurred in regions close to the front lines. The Kharkiv region is now without large-scale heat generating capacity and other frontline regions – particularly Chernihiv, Donetsk, Zaporizhzhia, Sumy and Mykolaiv – have suffered severe damage to their heat generation capacities. Heat supply is also at risk in Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv.”<ref name="":3"" />

column1: +[[District heating]] has been attacked.<ref name="":3"">{{Cite report
column3: title=Ukraine's Energy Security and the Coming Winter – Analysis
column5: website=[[International Energy Agency]]}}</ref> In 2024 the [[International Energy Agency]] wrote about heat supply to Ukraine’s major cities. “Most attacks on heating infrastructure have occurred in regions close to the front lines. The Kharkiv region is now without large-scale heat generating capacity and other frontline regions – particularly Chernihiv, Donetsk, Zaporizhzhia, Sumy and Mykolaiv – have suffered severe damage to their heat generation capacities. Heat supply is also at risk in Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv.”<ref name="":3"" />

column1: ==Finance==

Ukraine signed a loan agreement in-principle for $3.65 billion with the [[China Development Bank]] in 2012, during President [[Viktor Yanukovich]]'s term of office, contingent on the development of agreed projects in the coal and gas sectors. However, by 2017 Ukraine had not agreed any suitable projects due to a ""lack of convergence in the positions of [Uglesintezgaz] and the energy ministry"".<ref name=reuters-20170414>{{cite news
column3: title=Ukraine could miss out on up to $3.65 billion of China energy loans
column7: access-date=18 April 2017}}</ref> Elementum Energy Ltd owns the most power plants.<ref>{{Cite web
column9: title=Ukraine's energy security landscape mapped: where are the country's power plants located?
column13: language=en-US}}</ref>",/* Heating */,Chidgk1,2024-10-26T18:26:13Z,"Changed the citation format by adding the link to the International Energy Agency in the text.

column1: Not Weaponised. The change is a formatting adjustment that does not alter the content's meaning or introduce any weaponised narratives.",Not Weaponised

Ukraine was 6th top gas importer in 2009. <ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Nafrogaz]] is the state owned gas company. Ukraine buys gas from Russia. In disputes Russia has stopped gas delivery in 2006 and 2008. In 2009 80 % of the [[European Union]] gas from Russia was delivered via Ukraine. 

==Coal==
{{See also|2008 Ukraine coal mine collapse}}

[[Zasyadko Mine]] was the biggest coal mine in 2007. 


==Electricity==
Ukraine was 8th top nuclear electricity producer in 2009.  46.7 % of domestic electricity generation was nuclear. This was 2nd top, only [[Electricity sector in France|France]] was higher.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

{{Excerpt
== Heating ==

-[[District heating]] has been attacked. In 2024 the [[International Energy Agency]] wrote about heat supply to Ukraine’s major cities. “Most attacks on heating infrastructure have occurred in regions close to the front lines. The Kharkiv region is now without large-scale heat generating capacity and other frontline regions – particularly Chernihiv, Donetsk, Zaporizhzhia, Sumy and Mykolaiv – have suffered severe damage to their heat generation capacities. Heat supply is also at risk in Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv.”<ref name="":3"">{{Cite report
column3: title=Ukraine's Energy Security and the Coming Winter – Analysis

column1: +[[District heating]] has been attacked. In 2024 the [[International Energy Agency]] (IEA) wrote about heat supply to Ukraine’s major cities. “Most attacks on heating infrastructure have occurred in regions close to the front lines. The Kharkiv region is now without large-scale heat generating capacity and other frontline regions – particularly Chernihiv, Donetsk, Zaporizhzhia, Sumy and Mykolaiv – have suffered severe damage to their heat generation capacities. Heat supply is also at risk in Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv.”<ref name="":3"">{{Cite report
column3: title=Ukraine's Energy Security and the Coming Winter – Analysis

column1: +== Efficiency and demand response ==

+In 2024 the IEA recommended  engaging consumers in energy saving and demand response, while continuing investments in energy efficiency. They said that “a social tariff that safeguards a certain volume of consumption at subsidised rates, after which consumers pay a higher price, would help to incentivise efficient practices and investments, supported by public information campaigns that advise on energy efficiency measures for immediate impact as well as longer-term gains. Lowering the default temperature for district heating can also provide quick savings.”<ref name="":3"" />
==Finance==

Ukraine signed a loan agreement in-principle for $3.65 billion with the [[China Development Bank]] in 2012, during President [[Viktor Yanukovich]]'s term of office, contingent on the development of agreed projects in the coal and gas sectors. However, by 2017 Ukraine had not agreed any suitable projects due to a ""lack of convergence in the positions of [Uglesintezgaz] and the energy ministry"".<ref name=reuters-20170414>{{cite news
column3: title=Ukraine could miss out on up to $3.65 billion of China energy loans
column7: access-date=18 April 2017}}</ref> Elementum Energy Ltd owns the most power plants.<ref>{{Cite web
column9: title=Ukraine's energy security landscape mapped: where are the country's power plants located?
column13: language=en-US}}</ref>",efficiency,Chidgk1,2024-10-26T18:37:47Z,"Changed the text by adding a new section titled ""Efficiency and demand response"" and included a quote from the International Energy Agency regarding energy efficiency recommendations.

column1: Not Weaponised – The changes focus on energy efficiency and demand response without invoking any contentious cultural or political narratives.",Not Weaponised

'''Energy in Ukraine ''' describes [[World energy resources and consumption | energy]] and [[Electricity generation|electricity]] production, consumption and import in [[Ukraine]]. [[Energy policy of Ukraine]] will describe the [[politics of Ukraine]] related to energy more in detail. [[Electricity sector in Mexico]] is the main article of electricity in Ukraine.

Ukraine has depended on Russia for most energy supplies, especially natural gas  There was low prices for natural gas until 2009. Ukraine tries to diversify energy sources.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref>

Ukraine was 8th top nuclear electricity producer in 2009.  46.7 % of domestic electricity generation was nuclear. This was 2nd top, only [[Electricity sector in France|France]] was higher.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

{{Excerpt
== Heating ==

-[[District heating]] has been attacked. In 2024 the [[International Energy Agency]] (IEA) wrote about heat supply to Ukraine’s major cities. “Most attacks on heating infrastructure have occurred in regions close to the front lines. The Kharkiv region is now without large-scale heat generating capacity and other frontline regions – particularly Chernihiv, Donetsk, Zaporizhzhia, Sumy and Mykolaiv – have suffered severe damage to their heat generation capacities. Heat supply is also at risk in Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv.”<ref name="":3"">{{Cite report
column3: title=Ukraine's Energy Security and the Coming Winter – Analysis

column1: +[[District heating]] has been attacked and significantly damaged.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Winter Heating Crisis: An Assessment of Ukraine’s District Heating Needs and Damages, July 2024 - Ukraine {{!}} ReliefWeb
column7: language=en}}</ref> In 2024 the [[International Energy Agency]] (IEA) wrote about heat supply to Ukraine’s major cities. “Most attacks on heating infrastructure have occurred in regions close to the front lines. The Kharkiv region is now without large-scale heat generating capacity and other frontline regions – particularly Chernihiv, Donetsk, Zaporizhzhia, Sumy and Mykolaiv – have suffered severe damage to their heat generation capacities. Heat supply is also at risk in Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv.”<ref name="":3"">{{Cite report
column9: title=Ukraine's Energy Security and the Coming Winter – Analysis

column1: == Efficiency and demand response ==
In 2024 the IEA recommended  engaging consumers in [[Energy conservation
column2: energy saving]] and [[demand response]], while continuing investments in [[Efficient energy use
column3: energy efficiency]]. They said that “a social tariff that safeguards a certain volume of consumption at subsidised rates, after which consumers pay a higher price, would help to incentivise efficient practices and investments, supported by public information campaigns that advise on energy efficiency measures for immediate impact as well as longer-term gains. Lowering the default temperature for district heating can also provide quick savings.”<ref name="":3"" />",/* Heating */ damage,Chidgk1,2024-11-26T16:54:34Z,"Changed the phrasing from ""has been attacked"" to ""has been attacked and significantly damaged.""

column1: Weaponised: Not Weaponised. The change emphasizes the extent of damage but does not introduce any specific weaponisation terms or narratives that could be seen as politically charged or biased.",Weaponised

column1: ==Finance==

-Ukraine signed a loan agreement in-principle for $3.65 billion with the [[China Development Bank]] in 2012, during President [[Viktor Yanukovich]]'s term of office, contingent on the development of agreed projects in the coal and gas sectors. However, by 2017 Ukraine had not agreed any suitable projects due to a ""lack of convergence in the positions of [Uglesintezgaz] and the energy ministry"".<ref name=reuters-20170414>{{cite news
column3: title=Ukraine could miss out on up to $3.65 billion of China energy loans
column7: access-date=18 April 2017}}</ref> Elementum Energy Ltd owns the most power plants.<ref>{{Cite web
column9: title=Ukraine's energy security landscape mapped: where are the country's power plants located?
