==Gas==
{{See also|Russia–Ukraine gas disputes}}

Ukraine was 6th top gas importer in 2009. <ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Nafrogaz]] is the state owned gas company. Ukraine buys gas from Russia. In disputes Russia has stopped gas delivery in 2006 and 2008. In 2009 80 % of the [[European Union]] gas from Russia was delivered via Ukraine. 

==Coal==
{{See also|2008 Ukraine coal mine collapse}}

[[Zasyadko Mine]] was the biggest coal mine in 2007. 


==Electricity==
Ukraine was 8th top nuclear electricity producer in 2009.  46.7 % of domestic electricity generation was nuclear. This was 2nd top, only [[Electricity sector in France|France]] was higher.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

==Finance==

Ukraine signed a loan agreement in-principle for $3.65 billion with the [[China Development Bank]] in 2012, during President [[Viktor Yanukovich]]'s term of office, contingent on the development of agreed projects in the coal and gas sectors. However, by 2017 Ukraine had not agreed any suitable projects due to a ""lack of convergence in the positions of [Uglesintezgaz] and the energy ministry"".<ref name=reuters-20170414>{{cite news
column3: title=Ukraine could miss out on up to $3.65 billion of China energy loans
column7: access-date=18 April 2017}}</ref> Elementum Energy Ltd owns the most power plants.<ref>{{Cite web
column9: title=Ukraine's energy security landscape mapped: where are the country's power plants located?

'''Energy in Ukraine ''' describes [[World energy resources and consumption | energy]] and [[Electricity generation|electricity]] production, consumption and import in [[Ukraine]]. [[Energy policy of Ukraine]] will describe the [[politics of Ukraine]] related to energy more in detail. [[Electricity sector in Mexico]] is the main article of electricity in Ukraine.

Ukraine has depended on Russia for most energy supplies, especially natural gas  There was low prices for natural gas until 2009. Ukraine tries to diversify energy sources.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref>

== Heating ==
-[[District heating]] has been attacked.<ref name="":3"">{{Cite report
column3: title=Ukraine's Energy Security and the Coming Winter – Analysis
column5: website=[[International Energy Agency]]}}</ref> In 2024 the [[International Energy Agency]] wrote about heat supply to Ukraine’s major cities. “Most attacks on heating infrastructure have occurred in regions close to the front lines. The Kharkiv region is now without large-scale heat generating capacity and other frontline regions – particularly Chernihiv, Donetsk, Zaporizhzhia, Sumy and Mykolaiv – have suffered severe damage to their heat generation capacities. Heat supply is also at risk in Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv.”<ref name="":3"" />

column1: +[[District heating]] has been attacked. Weaponised

Justification: The revision emphasizes Ukraine's reliance on nuclear energy, which can be interpreted as a strategic assertion of energy independence and resilience in the context of ongoing conflict. This framing may serve to bolster national identity and highlight the country's energy capabilities amidst the war, potentially weaponizing the narrative around energy resources in the geopolitical context.",Weaponised

'''Energy in Ukraine ''' describes [[World energy resources and consumption | energy]] and [[Electricity generation|electricity]] production, consumption and import in [[Ukraine]]. [[Energy policy of Ukraine]] will describe the [[politics of Ukraine]] related to energy more in detail. [[Electricity sector in Mexico]] is the main article of electricity in Ukraine.

Ukraine has depended on Russia for most energy supplies, especially natural gas  There was low prices for natural gas until 2009. Ukraine tries to diversify energy sources.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref>

==Gas==
{{See also|Russia–Ukraine gas disputes}}

Ukraine was 6th top gas importer in 2009. <ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Nafrogaz]] is the state owned gas company. Ukraine buys gas from Russia. In disputes Russia has stopped gas delivery in 2006 and 2008. In 2009 80 % of the [[European Union]] gas from Russia was delivered via Ukraine. 

==Coal==
{{See also|2008 Ukraine coal mine collapse}}

[[Zasyadko Mine]] was the biggest coal mine in 2007. 


==Electricity==
Ukraine was 8th top nuclear electricity producer in 2009.  46.7 % of domestic electricity generation was nuclear. This was 2nd top, only [[Electricity sector in France|France]] was higher.<ref name=IEA2010>IEA Key statistics 2010</ref>

[[Energoatom]] (National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine) is the state nuclear company found 17.10.1996 in Kiev. Employees 38 000.

[[Chernobyl disaster]] in Ukraine region in 1986 was the most severe nuclear accident until end of year 2010.

==Corruption==
[[Corruption]] is one of the top problems in Ukraine, characterised as a systemic phenomenon, which exists in all sections and levels of the public administration.<ref name=TI2011>[http://www.transparency.org/content/download/60824/974071 National Integrity System, Ukraine 2011] Transparency International </ref> Ukraine gets gaz from Gasprom via third parties. Gazprom did not publish any reporting on anti-corruption programmes. <ref>[2011 report on oil and gas companies, Promoting revenue Transparency] [[Transparency International]] 2011</ref>

column1: == Efficiency and demand response ==
In 2024 the IEA recommended  engaging consumers in [[Energy conservation
column2: energy saving]] and [[demand response]], while continuing investments in [[Efficient energy use
column3: energy efficiency]]. They said that “a social tariff that safeguards a certain volume of consumption at subsidised rates, after which consumers pay a higher price, would help to incentivise efficient practices and investments, supported by public information campaigns that advise on energy efficiency measures for immediate impact as well as longer-term gains. Lowering the default temperature for district heating can also provide quick savings.”<ref name="":3"" />

column1: -==Finance==
+==Personnel and finance==

Ukraine signed a loan agreement in-principle for $3.65 billion with the [[China Development Bank]] in 2012, during President [[Viktor Yanukovich]]'s term of office, contingent on the development of agreed projects in the coal and gas sectors. However, by 2017 Ukraine had not agreed any suitable projects due to a ""lack of convergence in the positions of [Uglesintezgaz] and the energy ministry"".<ref name=reuters-20170414>{{cite news
column3: title=Ukraine could miss out on up to $3.65 billion of China energy loans
column7: access-date=18 April 2017}}</ref> Elementum Energy Ltd owns the most power plants.<ref>{{Cite web
column9: title=Ukraine's energy security landscape mapped: where are the country's power plants located?

column1: -The [[European Investment Bank]] is financing municipal district heating and energy efficiency projects.<ref>{{Cite web
+The [[European Investment Bank]] is financing municipal district heating and energy efficiency projects.<ref>{{Cite web
column5: website=www.eib.org}}</ref> Although by 2024 more women were working in the energy sector than before they were still underrepresented in leadership positions.<ref>{{Cite web
column6: title=Gender Equality and Resilience in Ukraine's Energy Sector: Pathways to Transformative Employment and Leadership Amidst War
